qapairs: [{"answer": "Willie Brown", "question": "Who said he would start a drive to recall Schwarzenegger?"}, {"answer": "cleaning up gridlock", "question": "What was Schwarzenegger's mandate?"}, {"answer": "Saturday Night Live", "question": "What was Schwarzenegger's sketch \"Hans and Franz\"?"}]
context: As soon as Schwarzenegger was elected governor, Willie Brown said he would start a drive to recall the governor. Schwarzenegger was equally entrenched in what he considered to be his mandate in cleaning up gridlock. Building on a catchphrase from the sketch "Hans and Franz" from Saturday Night Live (which partly parodied his bodybuilding career), Schwarzenegger called the Democratic State politicians "girlie men".

qapairs: [{"answer": "repealing an unpopular increase in the vehicle registration fee", "question": "What did Schwarzenegger's early victories include?"}, {"answer": "November 2005", "question": "When did Schwarzenegger call a special election?"}, {"answer": "California", "question": "What state did Schwarzenegger vow to continue to seek consensus for?"}, {"answer": "160 million dollars", "question": "How much did Schwarzenegger's opposition raise to defeat him?"}, {"answer": "Knox v. Service Employees International Union", "question": "In what case did the Supreme Court find that the use of compulsory fundraising was illegal?"}]
context: Schwarzenegger's early victories included repealing an unpopular increase in the vehicle registration fee as well as preventing driver's licenses being given out to illegal immigrants, but later he began to feel the backlash when powerful state unions began to oppose his various initiatives. Key among his reckoning with political realities was a special election he called in November 2005, in which four ballot measures he sponsored were defeated. Schwarzenegger accepted personal responsibility for the defeats and vowed to continue to seek consensus for the people of California. He would later comment that "no one could win if the opposition raised 160 million dollars to defeat you". The U.S. Supreme Court later found the public employee unions' use of compulsory fundraising during the campaign had been illegal in Knox v. Service Employees International Union, Local 1000.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Susan Kennedy", "question": "Who was Schwarzenegger's Chief of Staff?"}, {"answer": "a more politically moderate position", "question": "What did Schwarzenegger move towards?"}]
context: Schwarzenegger then went against the advice of fellow Republican strategists and appointed a Democrat, Susan Kennedy, as his Chief of Staff. Schwarzenegger gradually moved towards a more politically moderate position, determined to build a winning legacy with only a short time to go until the next gubernatorial election.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Phil Angelides", "question": "Who was the California State Treasurer?"}, {"answer": "56.0%", "question": "What percentage of the vote did Schwarzenegger win in 2006?"}, {"answer": "38.9%", "question": "What percentage of the vote did Schwarzenegger win re-election against Angelides?"}, {"answer": "moving away from the right and towards the center of the political spectrum", "question": "What did many commentators see Schwarzenegger as in recent years?"}, {"answer": "San Francisco", "question": "Where was Gavin Newsom mayor?"}, {"answer": "center-left", "question": "What did Gavin Newsom say about Schwarzenegger?"}]
context: Schwarzenegger ran for re-election against Democrat Phil Angelides, the California State Treasurer, in the 2006 elections, held on November 7, 2006. Despite a poor year nationally for the Republican party, Schwarzenegger won re-election with 56.0% of the vote compared with 38.9% for Angelides, a margin of well over one million votes. In recent years, many commentators have seen Schwarzenegger as moving away from the right and towards the center of the political spectrum. After hearing a speech by Schwarzenegger at the 2006 Martin Luther King, Jr. breakfast, San Francisco mayor Gavin Newsom said that, "[H]e's becoming a Democrat [… H]e's running back, not even to the center. I would say center-left".

qapairs: [{"answer": "2010", "question": "When was Schwarzenegger rumored to run for the Senate?"}, {"answer": "false", "question": "What was Schwarzenegger rumored to be?"}]
context: It was rumored that Schwarzenegger might run for the United States Senate in 2010, as his governorship would be term-limited by that time. This turned out to be false.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Wendy Leigh", "question": "Who wrote an unofficial biography on Schwarzenegger?"}, {"answer": "Leigh", "question": "Who portrays Schwarzenegger as obsessed with power?"}, {"answer": "100%", "question": "How much of Schwarzenegger's potential did leaders use?"}, {"answer": "married into a political family", "question": "What did Schwarzenegger say he wanted to enter politics?"}, {"answer": "reaching out to help people", "question": "How did Schwarzenegger say he wanted to be a public servant?"}, {"answer": "Eunice and Sargent Shriver", "question": "Who became Schwarzenegger's heroes?"}, {"answer": "Eunice Kennedy Shriver", "question": "Who was the sister of John F. Kennedy?"}, {"answer": "he is not a natural born citizen of the United States", "question": "What is Schwarzenegger's status as president?"}, {"answer": "Demolition Man", "question": "What is the name of the Sylvester Stallone movie?"}]
context: Wendy Leigh, who wrote an unofficial biography on Schwarzenegger, claims he plotted his political rise from an early age using the movie business and bodybuilding as building blocks to escape a depressing home. Leigh portrays Schwarzenegger as obsessed with power and quotes him as saying, "I wanted to be part of the small percentage of people who were leaders, not the large mass of followers. I think it is because I saw leaders use 100% of their potential – I was always fascinated by people in control of other people." Schwarzenegger has said that it was never his intention to enter politics, but he says, "I married into a political family. You get together with them and you hear about policy, about reaching out to help people. I was exposed to the idea of being a public servant and Eunice and Sargent Shriver became my heroes." Eunice Kennedy Shriver was sister of John F. Kennedy, and mother-in-law to Schwarzenegger; Sargent Shriver is husband to Eunice and father-in-law to Schwarzenegger. He cannot run for president as he is not a natural born citizen of the United States. In The Simpsons Movie (2007), he is portrayed as the president, and in the Sylvester Stallone movie, Demolition Man (1993, ten years before his first run for political office), it is revealed that a constitutional amendment passed which allowed Schwarzenegger to become president.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Anna Richardson", "question": "Who settled a libel lawsuit against Schwarzenegger?"}, {"answer": "The parties are content to put this matter behind them and are pleased that this legal dispute has now been settled", "question": "What did Anna Richardson say the parties are pleased with the settlement of the libel lawsuit?"}, {"answer": "The 6th Day", "question": "For what event did Richardson claim Schwarzenegger touched her breast during a press event?"}, {"answer": "Los Angeles Times", "question": "In what newspaper did Anna Richardson claim Walsh and Main libeled Schwarzenegger?"}]
context: British television personality Anna Richardson settled a libel lawsuit in August 2006 against Schwarzenegger, his top aide, Sean Walsh, and his publicist, Sheryl Main. A joint statement read: "The parties are content to put this matter behind them and are pleased that this legal dispute has now been settled." Richardson claimed they tried to tarnish her reputation by dismissing her allegations that Schwarzenegger touched her breast during a press event for The 6th Day in London. She claimed Walsh and Main libeled her in a Los Angeles Times article when they contended she encouraged his behavior.

qapairs: [{"answer": "October 2013", "question": "When did the New York Post report that Schwarzenegger was exploring a future run for president?"}, {"answer": "Article II, Section I, Clause V", "question": "What clause prevents individuals who are not natural-born citizens from assuming the office?"}, {"answer": "constitutional change", "question": "What has Schwarzenegger reportedly been lobbying legislators about?"}, {"answer": "Columbia University law professor", "question": "What professor observed that Schwarzenegger's lawsuit could ultimately win him the right to run for office?"}]
context: In October 2013, the New York Post reported that Schwarzenegger was exploring a future run for president. The former California governor would face a constitutional hurdle; Article II, Section I, Clause V nominally prevents individuals who are not natural-born citizens of the United States from assuming the office. He has reportedly been lobbying legislators about a possible constitutional change, or filing a legal challenge to the provision. Columbia University law professor Michael Dorf observed that Schwarzenegger's possible lawsuit could ultimately win him the right to run for the office, noting, "The law is very clear, but it’s not 100 percent clear that the courts would enforce that law rather than leave it to the political process."

qapairs: [{"answer": "1919", "question": "When was Nancy Astor elected the first female member of parliament to take office in the British Houses of Parliament for the constituency of Plymouth Sutton?"}, {"answer": "Waldorf Astor", "question": "Who was Nancy Astor's husband?"}, {"answer": "18 October 1928", "question": "When was Plymouth granted city status?"}, {"answer": "Plymstock", "question": "What parish was Plymouth's first Lord Mayor?"}]
context: In 1919 Nancy Astor was elected the first ever female member of parliament to take office in the British Houses of Parliament for the constituency of Plymouth Sutton. Taking over office from her husband Waldorf Astor, Lady Astor was a vibrantly active campaigner for her resident constituents . Plymouth was granted city status on 18 October 1928. The city's first Lord Mayor was appointed in 1935 and its boundaries further expanded in 1967 to include the town of Plympton and the parish of Plymstock.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1974 Health and Safety at Work Act", "question": "What Act was Michael Foot responsible for?"}, {"answer": "Michael Foot", "question": "Who was elected Labour MP in 1945?"}]
context: In 1945, Plymouth-born Michael Foot was elected Labour MP for the war-torn constituency of Plymouth Devonport and after serving as Secretary of State for Education and responsible for the 1974 Health and Safety at Work Act, went on to become one of the most distinguished leaders of the Labour party.

qapairs: [{"answer": "King George V", "question": "Who granted Plymouth the dignity of Lord Mayor in 1935?"}, {"answer": "six", "question": "How many councillors are in Plymouth?"}, {"answer": "the Deputy Lord Mayor", "question": "What does the Lord Mayor choose?"}, {"answer": "Dr John Mahony", "question": "Who is the incumbent for 2015-16?"}]
context: Plymouth was granted the dignity of Lord Mayor by King George V in 1935. The position is elected each year by a group of six councillors. It is traditional that the position of the Lord Mayor alternates between the Conservative Party and the Labour Party annually and that the Lord Mayor chooses the Deputy Lord Mayor. Conservative councillor Dr John Mahony is the incumbent for 2015–16.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1970s", "question": "In what decade did Oklahoma City have its share of very brutal crimes?"}, {"answer": "1978", "question": "When was the worst crime in Oklahoma City?"}, {"answer": "Sirloin Stockade", "question": "What restaurant was murdered in 1978?"}, {"answer": "Purcell, Oklahoma", "question": "In what city were the three people killed?"}, {"answer": "Harold Stafford", "question": "Who died in a motorcycle accident in Tulsa?"}, {"answer": "Verna Stafford", "question": "Who was sentenced to life without parole after being granted a new trial?"}, {"answer": "1995", "question": "When was Roger Dale Stafford executed?"}]
context: Oklahoma City also has its share of very brutal crimes, particularly in the 1970s. The worst of which occurred in 1978, when six employees of a Sirloin Stockade restaurant on the city's south side were murdered execution-style in the restaurant's freezer. An intensive investigation followed, and the three individuals involved, who also killed three others in Purcell, Oklahoma, were identified. One, Harold Stafford, died in a motorcycle accident in Tulsa not long after the restaurant murders. Another, Verna Stafford, was sentenced to life without parole after being granted a new trial after she had previously been sentenced to death. Roger Dale Stafford, considered the mastermind of the murder spree, was executed by lethal injection at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary in 1995.

qapairs: [{"answer": "UNFPA", "question": "Who did President Bush deny funding to?"}, {"answer": "$244 million", "question": "How much money was blocked by the Executive Branch over the course of the Bush administration?"}]
context: President Bush denied funding to the UNFPA. Over the course of the Bush Administration, a total of $244 million in Congressionally approved funding was blocked by the Executive Branch.

qapairs: [{"answer": "deputy Prime Minister", "question": "Who was Malenkov demoted to on February 8, 1955?"}, {"answer": "February 8, 1955", "question": "On what date was Malenkov officially demoted to deputy Prime Minister?"}, {"answer": "Nikita Khrushchev", "question": "Who was the First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party?"}, {"answer": "Nikita Khrushchev", "question": "Who was the First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party?"}]
context: On February 8, 1955, Malenkov was officially demoted to deputy Prime Minister. As First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, Nikita Khrushchev's authority was significantly enhanced by Malenkov's demotion.

qapairs: [{"answer": "17\u20131946", "question": "When was the Council of People's Commissars known?"}, {"answer": "Boris Yeltsin", "question": "Who was the last president of the Russian SFSR?"}, {"answer": "Vladimir Lenin", "question": "Who was the first president of the Council of People's Commissars of the Russian SFSR?"}]
context: The Government was known officially as the Council of People's Commissars (1917–1946), Council of Ministers (1946–1978) and Council of Ministers–Government (1978–1991). The first government was headed by Vladimir Lenin as "Chairman of the Council of People's Commissars of the Russian SFSR" and the last by Boris Yeltsin as both head of government and head of state under the title "President".

qapairs: [{"answer": "The Inns of Court and Inns of Chancery", "question": "What were the inns where barristers met to do business in London?"}]
context: The Inns of Court and Inns of Chancery in London started as ordinary inns where barristers met to do business, but became institutions of the legal profession in England and Wales.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Parliament Square", "question": "Where is the Red Lion located?"}, {"answer": "Division bell", "question": "What is the name of the pub that summons MPs back to the chamber when they are required to take part in a vote?"}, {"answer": "Madonna and Guy Ritchie", "question": "Who owned the Punch Bowl in Mayfair?"}, {"answer": "Earls Court", "question": "Where was the Coleherne public house located?"}, {"answer": "Freddie Mercury, Kenny Everett and Rudolph Nureyev", "question": "Who were some of the well-known patrons of the Coleherne public house in Earls Court?"}, {"answer": "Colin Ireland", "question": "Who used the Coleherne public house to pick up victims?"}]
context: The Red Lion in Parliament Square is close to the Palace of Westminster and is consequently used by political journalists and members of parliament. The pub is equipped with a Division bell that summons MPs back to the chamber when they are required to take part in a vote. The Punch Bowl, Mayfair was at one time jointly owned by Madonna and Guy Ritchie. The Coleherne public house in Earls Court was a well-known gay pub from the 1950s. It attracted many well-known patrons, such as Freddie Mercury, Kenny Everett and Rudolph Nureyev. It was used by the serial-killer Colin Ireland to pick up victims.

qapairs: [{"answer": "eight", "question": "How many districts is Saint Helena divided into?"}, {"answer": "statistical subdivisions", "question": "What do the districts serve as?"}, {"answer": "twelve", "question": "How many representatives are elected to the Legislative Council of fifteen?"}]
context: Saint Helena is divided into eight districts, each with a community centre. The districts also serve as statistical subdivisions. The island is a single electoral area and elects twelve representatives to the Legislative Council of fifteen.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Queen Elizabeth II", "question": "Who vested executive authority in Saint Helena?"}, {"answer": "the British government", "question": "Who is the Governor of Saint Helena appointed by?"}, {"answer": "Defence and Foreign Affairs", "question": "What remain the responsibility of the United Kingdom?"}]
context: Executive authority in Saint Helena is vested in Queen Elizabeth II and is exercised on her behalf by the Governor of Saint Helena. The Governor is appointed by the Queen on the advice of the British government. Defence and Foreign Affairs remain the responsibility of the United Kingdom.

qapairs: [{"answer": "fifteen", "question": "How many seats are in the Legislative Council of Saint Helena?"}, {"answer": "Twelve", "question": "How many members of the Legislative Council of Saint Helena are elected every four years?"}, {"answer": "three", "question": "How many ex officio members are the Chief Secretary, Financial Secretary and Attorney General?"}, {"answer": "the Governor", "question": "Who presides the Executive Council?"}, {"answer": "Chief Minister", "question": "What is the name of the elected member of the Legislative Council of Saint Helena?"}, {"answer": "158 votes to 42", "question": "How many votes were defeated on a 10% turnout?"}]
context: There are fifteen seats in the Legislative Council of Saint Helena, a unicameral legislature, in addition to a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker. Twelve of the fifteen members are elected in elections held every four years. The three ex officio members are the Chief Secretary, Financial Secretary and Attorney General. The Executive Council is presided over by the Governor, and consists of three ex officio officers and five elected members of the Legislative Council appointed by the Governor. There is no elected Chief Minister, and the Governor acts as the head of government. In January 2013 it was proposed that the Executive Council would be led by a "Chief Councillor" who would be elected by the members of the Legislative Council and would nominate the other members of the Executive Council. These proposals were put to a referendum on 23 March 2013 where they were defeated by 158 votes to 42 on a 10% turnout.

qapairs: [{"answer": "April 2, 1958", "question": "When did Eisenhower launch the first satellite?"}, {"answer": "Lyndon B. Johnson", "question": "Who led the Senate Majority Leader?"}, {"answer": "July 29, 1958", "question": "When did Eisenhower pass the National Aeronautics and Space Act?"}, {"answer": "National Advisory Committee on Aeronautics", "question": "What was the name of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration?"}, {"answer": "Civilian-Military Liaison Committee", "question": "What was the name of the committee that created the National Aeronautics and Space Act?"}]
context: On April 2, 1958, President Eisenhower reacted to the Soviet space lead in launching the first satellite, by recommending to the US Congress that a civilian agency be established to direct nonmilitary space activities. Congress, led by Senate Majority Leader Lyndon B. Johnson, responded by passing the National Aeronautics and Space Act, which Eisenhower signed into law on July 29, 1958. This law turned the National Advisory Committee on Aeronautics into the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA). It also created a Civilian-Military Liaison Committee, chaired by the President, responsible for coordinating the nation's civilian and military space programs.

qapairs: [{"answer": "immutable divine and natural law", "question": "What are the universal positive ecclesiastical laws based upon?"}, {"answer": "pope", "question": "Who possesses the totality of legislative, executive, and judicial power in his person?"}, {"answer": "doctrinal or moral", "question": "What is the actual subject material of the canons?"}]
context: In the Roman Church, universal positive ecclesiastical laws, based upon either immutable divine and natural law, or changeable circumstantial and merely positive law, derive formal authority and promulgation from the office of pope, who as Supreme Pontiff possesses the totality of legislative, executive, and judicial power in his person. The actual subject material of the canons is not just doctrinal or moral in nature, but all-encompassing of the human condition.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Roman Law Code of Justinian", "question": "The legislative style was adapted from what?"}, {"answer": "collegiate panels of judges and an investigative form of proceeding", "question": "What type of ecclesiastical courts are called inquisitorial?"}, {"answer": "common law system of English and U.S. law", "question": "Where is the adversarial form of proceeding found?"}]
context: Much of the legislative style was adapted from the Roman Law Code of Justinian. As a result, Roman ecclesiastical courts tend to follow the Roman Law style of continental Europe with some variation, featuring collegiate panels of judges and an investigative form of proceeding, called "inquisitorial", from the Latin "inquirere", to enquire. This is in contrast to the adversarial form of proceeding found in the common law system of English and U.S. law, which features such things as juries and single judges.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Aristotelian-Thomistic", "question": "Canonical jurisprudential theory generally follows the principles of what legal philosophy?"}, {"answer": "law", "question": "What is never explicitly defined in the Code?"}]
context: Canonical jurisprudential theory generally follows the principles of Aristotelian-Thomistic legal philosophy. While the term "law" is never explicitly defined in the Code, the Catechism of the Catholic Church cites Aquinas in defining law as "...an ordinance of reason for the common good, promulgated by the one who is in charge of the community" and reformulates it as "...a rule of conduct enacted by competent authority for the sake of the common good."

qapairs: [{"answer": "Latin or Western Church", "question": "What was the state of the Eastern Catholic Churches in full union with Rome before 1917?"}, {"answer": "custom", "question": "What law played an important part in the Eastern Catholic Churches?"}, {"answer": "1929", "question": "When did Pius XI inform the Eastern Churches of his intention to work out a Code for the whole of the Eastern Church?"}, {"answer": "1949 through 1958", "question": "When was the publication of the Codes for the Eastern Churches?"}]
context: The law of the Eastern Catholic Churches in full union with Rome was in much the same state as that of the Latin or Western Church before 1917; much more diversity in legislation existed in the various Eastern Catholic Churches. Each had its own special law, in which custom still played an important part. In 1929 Pius XI informed the Eastern Churches of his intention to work out a Code for the whole of the Eastern Church. The publication of these Codes for the Eastern Churches regarding the law of persons was made between 1949 through 1958 but finalized nearly 30 years later.

qapairs: [{"answer": "March 22, 2012", "question": "When did the Somali Cabinet approve the National Communications Act?"}, {"answer": "consultations", "question": "How was the National Communications Act passed?"}, {"answer": "more efficient service delivery", "question": "What is the result of the National Communications Act?"}]
context: On March 22, 2012, the Somali Cabinet unanimously approved the National Communications Act, which paves the way for the establishment of a National Communications regulator in the broadcasting and telecommunications sectors. The bill was passed following consultations between government representatives and communications, academic and civil society stakeholders. According to the Ministry of Information, Posts and Telecommunication, the Act is expected to create an environment conducive to investment and the certainty it provides will encourage further infrastructural development, resulting in more efficient service delivery.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1990s", "question": "In what decade has Boston seen a great reduction in violent crime?"}, {"answer": "the Boston Police Department", "question": "Who credited Boston's low crime rate to?"}, {"answer": "\"Boston Miracle\"", "question": "What has been credited to the Boston Police Department's collaboration with neighborhood groups and church parishes to prevent youths from joining gangs?"}, {"answer": "152", "question": "How many murders were in Boston in 1990?"}]
context: Like many major American cities, Boston has seen a great reduction in violent crime since the early 1990s. Boston's low crime rate since the 1990s has been credited to the Boston Police Department's collaboration with neighborhood groups and church parishes to prevent youths from joining gangs, as well as involvement from the United States Attorney and District Attorney's offices. This helped lead in part to what has been touted as the "Boston Miracle". Murders in the city dropped from 152 in 1990 (for a murder rate of 26.5 per 100,000 people) to just 31—not one of them a juvenile—in 1999 (for a murder rate of 5.26 per 100,000).

qapairs: [{"answer": "John F. Kennedy Federal Office Building", "question": "What is the name of the federal building in Boston?"}, {"answer": "Thomas P. O'Neill Federal Building", "question": "What Federal Building is located in Boston?"}, {"answer": "United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit", "question": "What federal court is located in Boston?"}]
context: The city has several federal facilities, including the John F. Kennedy Federal Office Building, the Thomas P. O'Neill Federal Building, the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, and the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.

qapairs: [{"answer": "two", "question": "How many congressional districts are in Boston?"}, {"answer": "Mike Capuano", "question": "Who represented the northern three-fourths of Boston in 1998?"}, {"answer": "Stephen Lynch", "question": "Who represented the southern fourth district of Boston?"}, {"answer": "Republican", "question": "Who has not represented a significant portion of Boston in over a century?"}, {"answer": "Elizabeth Warren", "question": "Who is the state's senior member of the United States Senate?"}, {"answer": "Ed Markey", "question": "Who is the state's junior member of the United States Senate?"}]
context: Federally, Boston is split between two congressional districts. The northern three-fourths of the city is in the 7th district, represented by Mike Capuano since 1998. The southern fourth is in the 8th district, represented by Stephen Lynch. Both are Democrats; a Republican has not represented a significant portion of Boston in over a century. The state's senior member of the United States Senate is Democrat Elizabeth Warren, first elected in 2012. The state's junior member of the United States Senate is Democrat Ed Markey, who was elected in 2013 to succeed John Kerry after Kerry's appointment and confirmation as the United States Secretary of State.

qapairs: [{"answer": "2005", "question": "When did Paramount Pictures acquire DreamWorks SKG?"}, {"answer": "Stacey Snider", "question": "Who was Universal's longtime chairperson?"}, {"answer": "Marc Shmuger", "question": "Who replaced Stacey Snider?"}, {"answer": "Adam Fogelson", "question": "Who was the former president of worldwide marketing and distribution?"}, {"answer": "Donna Langley", "question": "Who was upped to co-chairperson?"}, {"answer": "Stephanie Sperber", "question": "Who founded Universal Partnerships & Licensing?"}, {"answer": "Donna Langley", "question": "Who did Adam Fogelson promote to sole-chairman?"}, {"answer": "Jeff Shell", "question": "Who was NBCUniversal International Chairman?"}, {"answer": "Ron Meyer", "question": "Who would give up oversight of Universal's film studio?"}, {"answer": "Universal Parks and Resorts", "question": "What does Meyers still have oversight of?"}]
context: In late 2005, Viacom's Paramount Pictures acquired DreamWorks SKG after acquisition talks between GE and DreamWorks stalled. Universal's long time chairperson, Stacey Snider, left the company in early 2006 to head up DreamWorks. Snider was replaced by then-Vice Chairman Marc Shmuger and Focus Features head David Linde. On October 5, 2009, Marc Shmuger and David Linde were ousted and their co-chairperson jobs consolidated under former president of worldwide marketing and distribution Adam Fogelson becoming the single chairperson. Donna Langley was also upped to co-chairperson. In 2009, Stephanie Sperber founded Universal Partnerships & Licensing within Universal to license consumer products for Universal. In September 2013, Adam Fogelson was ousted as co-chairman of Universal Pictures, promoting Donna Langley to sole-chairman. In addition, NBCUniversal International Chairman, Jeff Shell, would be appointed as Chairman of the newly created Filmed Entertainment Group. Longtime studio head Ron Meyer would give up oversight of the film studio and appointed Vice Chairman of NBCUniversal, providing consultation to CEO Steve Burke on all of the company's operations. Meyers still retains oversight of Universal Parks and Resorts.

qapairs: [{"answer": "enactments, adjustments, and repeals", "question": "What has happened to the world since then?"}, {"answer": "Daylight saving time", "question": "Where is an overview of the world's enactments, adjustments, and repeals available?"}]
context: Since then, the world has seen many enactments, adjustments, and repeals. For specific details, an overview is available at Daylight saving time by country.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1907", "question": "When was Willett's proposal finalized?"}, {"answer": "Harrods", "question": "Who was Edward VII's managing director?"}, {"answer": "Napier Shaw", "question": "Who was the director of the Meteorological Office?"}, {"answer": "1909", "question": "When was the Parliament committee vote narrowly defeated?"}, {"answer": "1911 through 1914", "question": "From what years did Willett's allies introduce similar bills every year?"}, {"answer": "Andrew Peters", "question": "Who introduced a DST bill to the US House of Representatives in May 1909?"}]
context: The fate of Willett's 1907 proposal illustrates several political issues involved. The proposal attracted many supporters, including Balfour, Churchill, Lloyd George, MacDonald, Edward VII (who used half-hour DST at Sandringham), the managing director of Harrods, and the manager of the National Bank. However, the opposition was stronger: it included Prime Minister H. H. Asquith, Christie (the Astronomer Royal), George Darwin, Napier Shaw (director of the Meteorological Office), many agricultural organizations, and theatre owners. After many hearings the proposal was narrowly defeated in a Parliament committee vote in 1909. Willett's allies introduced similar bills every year from 1911 through 1914, to no avail. The US was even more skeptical: Andrew Peters introduced a DST bill to the US House of Representatives in May 1909, but it soon died in committee.

qapairs: [{"answer": "54.5%", "question": "What percentage of Queensland voters voted against daylight saving in 1992?"}, {"answer": "2005", "question": "When did the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association and the National Association of Convenience Stores lobby for the 2007 extension to US DST?"}, {"answer": "Daylight Saving for South East Queensland", "question": "What political party was registered in Queensland in December 2008?"}, {"answer": "DS4SEQ", "question": "Who contested the March 2009 Queensland State election?"}, {"answer": "55%", "question": "How many Western Australians voted against DST in 2009?"}, {"answer": "Peter Wellington", "question": "Who introduced the Daylight Saving for South East Queensland Referendum Bill 2010 into Queensland Parliament?"}, {"answer": "15 June 2011", "question": "When was the Daylight Saving for South East Queensland Referendum Bill defeated?"}]
context: In 1992, after a three-year trial of daylight saving in Queensland, Australia, a referendum on daylight saving was held and defeated with a 54.5% 'no' vote – with regional and rural areas strongly opposed, while those in the metropolitan south-east were in favor. In 2005, the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association and the National Association of Convenience Stores successfully lobbied for the 2007 extension to US DST. In December 2008, the Daylight Saving for South East Queensland (DS4SEQ) political party was officially registered in Queensland, advocating the implementation of a dual-time zone arrangement for Daylight Saving in South East Queensland while the rest of the state maintains standard time. DS4SEQ contested the March 2009 Queensland State election with 32 candidates and received one percent of the statewide primary vote, equating to around 2.5% across the 32 electorates contested. After a three-year trial, more than 55% of Western Australians voted against DST in 2009, with rural areas strongly opposed. On 14 April 2010, after being approached by the DS4SEQ political party, Queensland Independent member Peter Wellington, introduced the Daylight Saving for South East Queensland Referendum Bill 2010 into Queensland Parliament, calling for a referendum to be held at the next State election on the introduction of daylight saving into South East Queensland under a dual-time zone arrangement. The Bill was defeated in Queensland Parliament on 15 June 2011.

qapairs: [{"answer": "National Archives and Records Administration", "question": "What is the name of the NARA?"}, {"answer": "maintaining and publishing", "question": "What is the NARA responsible for?"}, {"answer": "Electoral College", "question": "Who does the NARA transmit votes to Congress?"}]
context: The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) is an independent agency of the United States government charged with preserving and documenting government and historical records and with increasing public access to those documents, which comprise the National Archives. NARA is officially responsible for maintaining and publishing the legally authentic and authoritative copies of acts of Congress, presidential proclamations and executive orders, and federal regulations. The NARA also transmits votes of the Electoral College to Congress.

qapairs: [{"answer": "The Archivist of the United States", "question": "Who oversees the operation of the National Archives and Records Administration?"}, {"answer": "when the constitutional threshold for passage has been reached", "question": "When does the Archivist declare an amendment to the U.S. Constitution?"}]
context: The Archivist of the United States is the chief official overseeing the operation of the National Archives and Records Administration. The Archivist not only maintains the official documentation of the passage of amendments to the U.S. Constitution by state legislatures, but has the authority to declare when the constitutional threshold for passage has been reached, and therefore when an act has become an amendment.

qapairs: [{"answer": "The Office of the Federal Register", "question": "Who publishes the Federal Register, Code of Federal Regulations, and United States Statutes at Large?"}, {"answer": "Electoral College", "question": "What does the Office of the Federal Register administer?"}]
context: The Office of the Federal Register publishes the Federal Register, Code of Federal Regulations, and United States Statutes at Large, among others. It also administers the Electoral College.

qapairs: [{"answer": "The Office of Government Information Services", "question": "What is OGIS?"}, {"answer": "reviewing FOIA policies, procedures and compliance of Federal agencies", "question": "What did Congress charge NARA with?"}, {"answer": "resolving FOIA disputes", "question": "What does NARA's mission include between Federal agencies and requesters?"}]
context: The Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) is a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) resource for the public and the government. Congress has charged NARA with reviewing FOIA policies, procedures and compliance of Federal agencies and to recommend changes to FOIA. NARA's mission also includes resolving FOIA disputes between Federal agencies and requesters.

qapairs: [{"answer": "records loss and destruction", "question": "What did the National Archives Establishment result in?"}, {"answer": "the Archivist of the United States", "question": "Who was the chief administrator of the National Archives Establishment?"}, {"answer": "1934", "question": "When was the National Archives Establishment established?"}, {"answer": "1949", "question": "When was the National Archives incorporated with GSA?"}]
context: Originally, each branch and agency of the U.S. government was responsible for maintaining its own documents, which often resulted in records loss and destruction. Congress established the National Archives Establishment in 1934 to centralize federal record keeping, with the Archivist of the United States as chief administrator. The National Archives was incorporated with GSA in 1949; in 1985 it became an independent agency as NARA (National Archives and Records Administration).

qapairs: [{"answer": "Executive Order 13526", "question": "What created the National Declassification Center?"}]
context: In 2010, Executive Order 13526 created the National Declassification Center to coordinate declassification practices across agencies, provide secure document services to other agencies, and review records in NARA custody for declassification.

qapairs: [{"answer": "the CPC Nanjing Committee Secretary", "question": "Who is the de facto governor of Nanjing?"}, {"answer": "the mayor", "question": "Who is the executive head of the government of Nanjing?"}, {"answer": "the CPC Nanjing Committee Secretary", "question": "Who is the de facto governor of Nanjing?"}]
context: At present, the full name of the government of Nanjing is "People's Government of Nanjing City" and the city is under the one-party rule of the CPC, with the CPC Nanjing Committee Secretary as the de facto governor of the city and the mayor as the executive head of the government working under the secretary.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Ed Policy", "question": "Who was named interim commissioner until Baker's replacement was found?"}, {"answer": "July 25, 2008", "question": "When did David Baker retire?"}, {"answer": "one year", "question": "How long did Baker think he would take over as commissioner of the AFL?"}, {"answer": "12", "question": "How many years did David Baker retire?"}, {"answer": "it's time", "question": "What is the time for David Baker to retire?"}]
context: After 12 years as commissioner of the AFL, David Baker retired unexpectedly on July 25, 2008, just two days before ArenaBowl XXII; deputy commissioner Ed Policy was named interim commissioner until Baker's replacement was found. Baker explained, "When I took over as commissioner, I thought it would be for one year. It turned into 12. But now it's time."

qapairs: [{"answer": "The City Council", "question": "What constitutes the executive government of the City of Bern?"}, {"answer": "five", "question": "How many councilors is the City Council composed of?"}, {"answer": "Stadtpr\u00e4sident", "question": "Who is the president of the executive department?"}, {"answer": "Alexander Tsch\u00e4pp\u00e4t", "question": "Who presides the City Council in the mandate period 2013-2016?"}, {"answer": "the City Council", "question": "Who is responsible for the implementation of laws decreed by the City Council?"}, {"answer": "every four years", "question": "How long is the regular election of the City Council held?"}, {"answer": "Any resident of Bern allowed to vote", "question": "Who can be elected as a member of the City Council?"}, {"answer": "Majorz", "question": "What is the name of the system that selects the delegates of the City Council?"}, {"answer": "the collegiate", "question": "Who assigns the heads of the other directorates?"}, {"answer": "Erlacherhof", "question": "Where does the executive body hold its meetings?"}]
context: The City Council (Gemeinderat) constitutes the executive government of the City of Bern and operates as a collegiate authority. It is composed of five councilors (German: Gemeinderat/-rätin), each presiding over a directorate (Direktion) comprising several departments and bureaus. The president of the executive department acts as mayor (Stadtpräsident). In the mandate period 2013–2016 (Legislatur) the City Council is presided by Stadtpräsident Alexander Tschäppät. Departmental tasks, coordination measures and implementation of laws decreed by the City Parliament are carried by the City Council. The regular election of the City Council by any inhabitant valid to vote is held every four years. Any resident of Bern allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the City Council. The delegates are selected by means of a system of Majorz. The mayor is elected as such as well by public election while the heads of the other directorates are assigned by the collegiate. The executive body holds its meetings in the Erlacherhof, built by architect Albrecht Stürler after 1747.

qapairs: [{"answer": "the mayor", "question": "What is one of the representatives of the SP?"}, {"answer": "25 November 2012", "question": "When was the last election held?"}]
context: As of 2015, Bern's City Council is made up of two representatives of the SP (Social Democratic Party, of whom one is also the mayor), and one each of CVP (Christian Democratic Party), GB (Green Alliance of Berne), and FDP (FDP.The Liberals), giving the left parties a majority of three out of five seats. The last election was held on 25 November 2012.

qapairs: [{"answer": "The City Parliament", "question": "What holds legislative power?"}, {"answer": "80", "question": "How many members is the City Parliament?"}, {"answer": "the City Council and the administration", "question": "Who executes regulations and by-laws?"}, {"answer": "delegates", "question": "Who is selected by means of a system of proportional representation?"}]
context: The City Parliament (de: Stadtrat, fr: Conseil de ville) holds legislative power. It is made up of 80 members, with elections held every four years. The City Parliament decrees regulations and by-laws that are executed by the City Council and the administration. The delegates are selected by means of a system of proportional representation.

qapairs: [{"answer": "public", "question": "What are the sessions of the City Parliament?"}, {"answer": "not politicians", "question": "What are members of the City Parliament?"}, {"answer": "Any resident of Bern allowed to vote", "question": "Who can be elected as a member of the City Parliament?"}, {"answer": "the Stadthaus", "question": "Where does the parliament hold its meetings?"}]
context: The sessions of the City Parliament are public. Unlike members of the City Council, members of the City Parliament are not politicians by profession, and they are paid a fee based on their attendance. Any resident of Bern allowed to vote can be elected as a member of the City Parliament. The parliament holds its meetings in the Stadthaus (Town Hall).

qapairs: [{"answer": "1857 to 1902", "question": "When was the Federal Palace built?"}]
context: The Federal Palace (Bundeshaus), built from 1857 to 1902, which houses the national parliament, government and part of the federal administration, can also be visited.

qapairs: [{"answer": "drug trafficking, money laundering, and human trafficking", "question": "What types of criminal enterprise can corruption facilitate?"}, {"answer": "political corruption", "question": "What is repression of political opponents and general police brutality considered?"}]
context: Forms of corruption vary, but include bribery, extortion, cronyism, nepotism, gombeenism, parochialism patronage, influence peddling, graft, and embezzlement. Corruption may facilitate criminal enterprise such as drug trafficking, money laundering, and human trafficking, though is not restricted to these activities. Misuse of government power for other purposes, such as repression of political opponents and general police brutality, is also considered political corruption.

qapairs: [{"answer": "depending on the country or jurisdiction", "question": "What are the activities that constitute illegal corruption differ?"}, {"answer": "political funding practices", "question": "What is legal in one place?"}, {"answer": "government officials", "question": "Who have broad or ill-defined powers?"}, {"answer": "over 1 trillion", "question": "How much US dollars is bribery estimated to involve?"}, {"answer": "kleptocracy", "question": "What is a state of unrestrained political corruption known as?"}]
context: The activities that constitute illegal corruption differ depending on the country or jurisdiction. For instance, some political funding practices that are legal in one place may be illegal in another. In some cases, government officials have broad or ill-defined powers, which make it difficult to distinguish between legal and illegal actions. Worldwide, bribery alone is estimated to involve over 1 trillion US dollars annually. A state of unrestrained political corruption is known as a kleptocracy, literally meaning "rule by thieves".

qapairs: [{"answer": "parish pump politics", "question": "What is parochialism also known as?"}]
context: Gombeenism refers to an individual who is dishonest and corrupt for the purpose of personal gain, more often through monetary, while, parochialism which is also known as parish pump politics relates to placing local or vanity projects ahead of the national interest.For instance in Irish politics, populist left wing political parties will often apply these terms to mainstream establisment political parties and will cite the many cases of Corruption in Ireland, such as the Irish Banking crisis, which found evidence of bribery, cronyism and collusion, where in some cases politicians who were coming to the end of their political careers would receive a senior management or committee position in a company they had dealings with.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Electoral fraud", "question": "What is illegal interference with the process of an election?"}, {"answer": "increasing the vote share of the favored candidate, depressing the vote share of the rival candidates", "question": "What do acts of fraud affect vote counts to bring about an election result?"}, {"answer": "voter fraud", "question": "What is another term for illegal voter registration?"}]
context: Electoral fraud is illegal interference with the process of an election. Acts of fraud affect vote counts to bring about an election result, whether by increasing the vote share of the favored candidate, depressing the vote share of the rival candidates, or both. Also called voter fraud, the mechanisms involved include illegal voter registration, intimidation at polls, and improper vote counting.

qapairs: [{"answer": "civil society and the rule of law disintegrate", "question": "What causes a corrupt dictatorship to disintegrate?"}, {"answer": "amass ever more wealth and power", "question": "What do corrupt dictators routinely ignore economic and social problems in their quest to do?"}]
context: A corrupt dictatorship typically results in many years of general hardship and suffering for the vast majority of citizens as civil society and the rule of law disintegrate. In addition, corrupt dictators routinely ignore economic and social problems in their quest to amass ever more wealth and power.

Council elections are held in early May for one third of the seats (one councillor for each ward), elected for a four-year term, so there are elections three years out of four. qapairs: [{"answer": "a party to either that fails to live up to their obligations", "question": "What can be held liable under international law?"}, {"answer": "international law", "question": "Under what law can a party to a party that fails to live up to their obligations be held liable?"}]
context: Treaties can be loosely compared to contracts: both are means of willing parties assuming obligations among themselves, and a party to either that fails to live up to their obligations can be held liable under international law.

qapairs: [{"answer": "late 19th century", "question": "When did most treaties follow a fairly consistent format?"}, {"answer": "a preamble", "question": "What describes the contracting parties and their joint objectives in executing the treaty?"}, {"answer": "a single very long sentence formatted into multiple paragraphs", "question": "Modern preambles are sometimes structured as what for readability?"}]
context: Since the late 19th century, most treaties have followed a fairly consistent format. A treaty typically begins with a preamble describing the contracting parties and their joint objectives in executing the treaty, as well as summarizing any underlying events (such as a war). Modern preambles are sometimes structured as a single very long sentence formatted into multiple paragraphs for readability, in which each of the paragraphs begins with a verb (desiring, recognizing, having, and so on).

qapairs: [{"answer": "the preamble", "question": "In what document are the full names of the contracting parties often included?"}]
context: The contracting parties' full names or sovereign titles are often included in the preamble, along with the full names and titles of their representatives, and a boilerplate clause about how their representatives have communicated (or exchanged) their full powers (i.e., the official documents appointing them to act on behalf of their respective states) and found them in good or proper form.

qapairs: [{"answer": "numbered articles", "question": "What contains the substance of the parties' actual agreement?"}, {"answer": "paragraph", "question": "What does each article heading usually include?"}, {"answer": "chapter headings", "question": "What may a long treaty group articles under?"}]
context: After the preamble comes numbered articles, which contain the substance of the parties' actual agreement. Each article heading usually encompasses a paragraph. A long treaty may further group articles under chapter headings.

qapairs: [{"answer": "where the final authentic copies of the treaty will be deposited", "question": "Where will the final authentic copies of the treaty be deposited?"}]
context: Modern treaties, regardless of subject matter, usually contain articles governing where the final authentic copies of the treaty will be deposited and how any subsequent disputes as to their interpretation will be peacefully resolved.

qapairs: [{"answer": "eschatocol", "question": "What is the end of a treaty called?"}, {"answer": "most formal, longest possible form", "question": "What is the date typically written in?"}, {"answer": "twenty-sixth day of June", "question": "When was the Charter of the United Nations issued?"}, {"answer": "stipulation that the versions in different languages are equally authentic", "question": "What is followed by a clause like \"in witness whereof\" or \"in faith whereof\"?"}]
context: The end of a treaty, the eschatocol (or closing protocol), is often signaled by a clause like "in witness whereof" or "in faith whereof," the parties have affixed their signatures, followed by the words "DONE at," then the site(s) of the treaty's execution and the date(s) of its execution. The date is typically written in its most formal, longest possible form. For example, the Charter of the United Nations was "DONE at the city of San Francisco the twenty-sixth day of June, one thousand nine hundred and forty-five." If the treaty is executed in multiple copies in different languages, that fact is always noted, and is followed by a stipulation that the versions in different languages are equally authentic.

qapairs: [{"answer": "signatures of the parties' representatives", "question": "What do the parties' representatives follow at the very end of a treaty?"}, {"answer": "an editor", "question": "Who will often append the dates on which the parties ratified the treaty and on which it came into effect for each party?"}]
context: The signatures of the parties' representatives follow at the very end. When the text of a treaty is later reprinted, such as in a collection of treaties currently in effect, an editor will often append the dates on which the respective parties ratified the treaty and on which it came into effect for each party.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Reservations", "question": "What are caveats to a state's acceptance of a treaty?"}, {"answer": "unilateral", "question": "Reservations are what type of statements purporting to exclude or modify the legal obligation and its effects on the reserving state?"}, {"answer": "at the time of signing or ratification", "question": "When must reservations be included?"}, {"answer": "a party cannot add a reservation after it has already joined a treaty", "question": "What is the term for a reservation that a party must include at the time of signing or ratification?"}]
context: Reservations are essentially caveats to a state's acceptance of a treaty. Reservations are unilateral statements purporting to exclude or to modify the legal obligation and its effects on the reserving state. These must be included at the time of signing or ratification, i.e. "a party cannot add a reservation after it has already joined a treaty".

qapairs: [{"answer": "international law", "question": "What law was unaccepting of treaty reservations?"}, {"answer": "encouraging the largest number of states to join treaties", "question": "What was the goal of international law?"}, {"answer": "they are not inconsistent with the goals and purposes of the treaty", "question": "What are some treaties allowed to do?"}]
context: Originally, international law was unaccepting of treaty reservations, rejecting them unless all parties to the treaty accepted the same reservations. However, in the interest of encouraging the largest number of states to join treaties, a more permissive rule regarding reservations has emerged. While some treaties still expressly forbid any reservations, they are now generally permitted to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the goals and purposes of the treaty.

qapairs: [{"answer": "reservations", "question": "When a state limits its treaty obligations, other states have the option to accept reservations, object to them, or object and oppose them?"}, {"answer": "accepting the reservation does not change the accepting state's legal obligations as concerns other parties to the treaty", "question": "What does not change the accepting state's legal obligations to each other?"}, {"answer": "drop out completely", "question": "What happens to the parts of the treaty affected by the reservation?"}, {"answer": "if the state objects and opposes", "question": "What happens if the state refuses to acknowledge the reserving state is a party to the treaty?"}, {"answer": "objecting and opposing state", "question": "Who refuses to acknowledge the reserving state is a party to the treaty?"}]
context: When a state limits its treaty obligations through reservations, other states party to that treaty have the option to accept those reservations, object to them, or object and oppose them. If the state accepts them (or fails to act at all), both the reserving state and the accepting state are relieved of the reserved legal obligation as concerns their legal obligations to each other (accepting the reservation does not change the accepting state's legal obligations as concerns other parties to the treaty). If the state opposes, the parts of the treaty affected by the reservation drop out completely and no longer create any legal obligations on the reserving and accepting state, again only as concerns each other. Finally, if the state objects and opposes, there are no legal obligations under that treaty between those two state parties whatsoever. The objecting and opposing state essentially refuses to acknowledge the reserving state is a party to the treaty at all.

qapairs: [{"answer": "merely becoming a party puts the treaty and all of its obligations in action", "question": "What does a treaty do?"}, {"answer": "implementing legislation", "question": "What is a change in the domestic law of a state party that will direct or enable it to fulfill treaty obligations?"}, {"answer": "local prosecution by a party for particular crimes", "question": "What is an example of a treaty requiring such legislation?"}]
context: Treaties may be seen as 'self-executing', in that merely becoming a party puts the treaty and all of its obligations in action. Other treaties may be non-self-executing and require 'implementing legislation'—a change in the domestic law of a state party that will direct or enable it to fulfill treaty obligations. An example of a treaty requiring such legislation would be one mandating local prosecution by a party for particular crimes.

qapairs: [{"answer": "disagreements", "question": "What is the division between the two often politicized in?"}, {"answer": "failure of its legislature to pass the necessary domestic laws", "question": "If a treaty requires implementing legislation, a state may be in default of its obligations by what?"}]
context: The division between the two is often not clear and is often politicized in disagreements within a government over a treaty, since a non-self-executing treaty cannot be acted on without the proper change in domestic law. If a treaty requires implementing legislation, a state may be in default of its obligations by the failure of its legislature to pass the necessary domestic laws.

qapairs: [{"answer": "when the wording does not seem clear or it is not immediately apparent how it should be applied in a perhaps unforeseen circumstance", "question": "When must the language of treaties be interpreted?"}, {"answer": "Vienna Convention", "question": "What convention states that treaties are to be interpreted \"in good faith\" according to the \"ordinary meaning given to the terms of the treaty in"}, {"answer": "maximum effectiveness", "question": "What do international legal experts often invoke?"}]
context: The language of treaties, like that of any law or contract, must be interpreted when the wording does not seem clear or it is not immediately apparent how it should be applied in a perhaps unforeseen circumstance. The Vienna Convention states that treaties are to be interpreted "in good faith" according to the "ordinary meaning given to the terms of the treaty in their context and in the light of its object and purpose." International legal experts also often invoke the 'principle of maximum effectiveness,' which interprets treaty language as having the fullest force and effect possible to establish obligations between the parties.

qapairs: [{"answer": "No one party to a treaty can impose its particular interpretation of the treaty upon the other parties", "question": "Who can impose its particular interpretation of the treaty upon the other parties?"}, {"answer": "if the other parties fail to explicitly disavow that initially unilateral interpretation", "question": "Consent may be implied if the other parties fail to explicitly disavow that initial unilateral interpretation?"}, {"answer": "an 'authentic interpretation'", "question": "What is the legal effect of adding another clause to the treaty?"}]
context: No one party to a treaty can impose its particular interpretation of the treaty upon the other parties. Consent may be implied, however, if the other parties fail to explicitly disavow that initially unilateral interpretation, particularly if that state has acted upon its view of the treaty without complaint. Consent by all parties to the treaty to a particular interpretation has the legal effect of adding another clause to the treaty – this is commonly called an 'authentic interpretation'.

qapairs: [{"answer": "recognition that the other side is a sovereign state", "question": "What does signing a treaty mean?"}, {"answer": "international law", "question": "Under what law does signing a treaty mean recognition that the other side is a sovereign state and that the agreement being considered is enforceable?"}, {"answer": "nations can be very careful about terming an agreement to be a treaty", "question": "What can nations be very careful about terming an agreement to be a treaty?"}, {"answer": "compacts", "question": "What are agreements between states in the United States?"}]
context: One significant part of treaty making is that signing a treaty implies recognition that the other side is a sovereign state and that the agreement being considered is enforceable under international law. Hence, nations can be very careful about terming an agreement to be a treaty. For example, within the United States, agreements between states are compacts and agreements between states and the federal government or between agencies of the government are memoranda of understanding.

qapairs: [{"answer": "one party wishes to create an obligation under international law", "question": "What happens when one party wishes to create an obligation under international law?"}, {"answer": "security guarantees and nuclear proliferation", "question": "What has been at work for discussions between North Korea and the United States?"}]
context: Another situation can occur when one party wishes to create an obligation under international law, but the other party does not. This factor has been at work with respect to discussions between North Korea and the United States over security guarantees and nuclear proliferation.

qapairs: [{"answer": "a treaty may and usually is named something other than a treaty", "question": "What is a convention, protocol, or simply agreement?"}, {"answer": "domestic law", "question": "The Treaty of Waitangi is internationally considered to be documents under what type of law?"}]
context: The terminology can also be confusing because a treaty may and usually is named something other than a treaty, such as a convention, protocol, or simply agreement. Conversely some legal documents such as the Treaty of Waitangi are internationally considered to be documents under domestic law.

qapairs: [{"answer": "permanently", "question": "What are treaties not necessarily binding upon the signatory parties?"}, {"answer": "consent of states", "question": "What are obligations in international law traditionally viewed as arising only from?"}, {"answer": "the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs", "question": "What provides that the treaty will terminate if, as a result of denunciations, the number of parties falls below 40?"}, {"answer": "expressly forbid withdrawal", "question": "What does the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs mean?"}, {"answer": "Article 56", "question": "What section of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties provides that when a treaty is silent over whether or not it can be denounced"}]
context: Treaties are not necessarily permanently binding upon the signatory parties. As obligations in international law are traditionally viewed as arising only from the consent of states, many treaties expressly allow a state to withdraw as long as it follows certain procedures of notification. For example, the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs provides that the treaty will terminate if, as a result of denunciations, the number of parties falls below 40. Many treaties expressly forbid withdrawal. Article 56 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties provides that where a treaty is silent over whether or not it can be denounced there is a rebuttable presumption that it cannot be unilaterally denounced unless:

qapairs: [{"answer": "sovereignty", "question": "Why can any state withdraw from a treaty at any time?"}, {"answer": "any state", "question": "Who can withdraw from any treaty at any time?"}, {"answer": "how other states will react to the withdrawal", "question": "What is the question of if a state can withdraw from a treaty at any time?"}]
context: In practice, because of sovereignty, any state can withdraw from any treaty at any time. The question of whether this is permitted is really a question of how other states will react to the withdrawal; for instance, another state might impose sanctions or go to war over a treaty violation.

qapairs: [{"answer": "withdrawal by one party from a bilateral treaty of course terminates the treaty", "question": "What happens if a state party withdraws from a bilateral treaty?"}, {"answer": "unless, of course, otherwise should or could be interpreted as agreed upon between the remaining states parties to the treaty", "question": "What happens when a state withdraws from a multi-lateral treaty?"}, {"answer": "[citation needed]", "question": "What does a state party need to do to withdraw from a multi-lateral treaty?"}]
context: If a state party's withdrawal is successful, its obligations under that treaty are considered terminated, and withdrawal by one party from a bilateral treaty of course terminates the treaty. When a state withdraws from a multi-lateral treaty, that treaty will still otherwise remain in force among the other parties, unless, of course, otherwise should or could be interpreted as agreed upon between the remaining states parties to the treaty.[citation needed]

qapairs: [{"answer": "temporarily suspending their obligations to that party", "question": "If a party has materially violated or breached its treaty obligations, the other parties may invoke this breach as grounds for what?"}, {"answer": "temporarily suspending their obligations to that party", "question": "If a party has materially violated or breached its treaty obligations, the other parties may invoke this breach as grounds for what?"}, {"answer": "temporarily suspending their obligations to that party", "question": "If a party has materially violated or breached its treaty obligations, the other parties may invoke this breach as grounds for what?"}, {"answer": "permanently terminating the treaty itself", "question": "What can a material breach be invoked as grounds for?"}]
context: If a party has materially violated or breached its treaty obligations, the other parties may invoke this breach as grounds for temporarily suspending their obligations to that party under the treaty. A material breach may also be invoked as grounds for permanently terminating the treaty itself.

qapairs: [{"answer": "does not automatically suspend or terminate treaty relations", "question": "What does a treaty breach do?"}, {"answer": "how the other parties regard the breach and how they resolve to respond to it", "question": "What does a treaty breach depend on?"}, {"answer": "a tribunal or other independent arbiter", "question": "Who determines the seriousness of a breach?"}, {"answer": "prematurely and perhaps wrongfully suspending or terminating its own obligations", "question": "What does an arbiter prevent a party from doing due to another's alleged material breach?"}]
context: A treaty breach does not automatically suspend or terminate treaty relations, however. It depends on how the other parties regard the breach and how they resolve to respond to it. Sometimes treaties will provide for the seriousness of a breach to be determined by a tribunal or other independent arbiter. An advantage of such an arbiter is that it prevents a party from prematurely and perhaps wrongfully suspending or terminating its own obligations due to another's alleged material breach.

qapairs: [{"answer": "self-termination", "question": "What do treaties sometimes include provisions for?"}, {"answer": "temporarily binding", "question": "What are some treaties intended to be?"}, {"answer": "under certain conditions", "question": "What is the purpose of the treaty?"}, {"answer": "[citation needed]", "question": "What does a treaty need to do to self-terminate if it is meant to exist only under certain conditions?"}]
context: Treaties sometimes include provisions for self-termination, meaning that the treaty is automatically terminated if certain defined conditions are met. Some treaties are intended by the parties to be only temporarily binding and are set to expire on a given date. Other treaties may self-terminate if the treaty is meant to exist only under certain conditions.[citation needed]

qapairs: [{"answer": "a fundamental change in circumstances", "question": "A party may claim that a treaty should be terminated if there has been what?"}, {"answer": "if unforeseen", "question": "What is a change in circumstances sufficient for a party to claim that a treaty should be terminated?"}, {"answer": "change brought about by its own breach of the treaty", "question": "What does a party not base a claim on?"}, {"answer": "invalidate", "question": "What can a party claim that a treaty should be terminated?"}, {"answer": "[citation needed]", "question": "What does a party claim that a treaty should be terminated if there has been a fundamental change in circumstances?"}]
context: A party may claim that a treaty should be terminated, even absent an express provision, if there has been a fundamental change in circumstances. Such a change is sufficient if unforeseen, if it undermined the “essential basis” of consent by a party, if it radically transforms the extent of obligations between the parties, and if the obligations are still to be performed. A party cannot base this claim on change brought about by its own breach of the treaty. This claim also cannot be used to invalidate treaties that established or redrew political boundaries.[citation needed]

qapairs: [{"answer": "an agent or body", "question": "Who gave a party's consent to a treaty?"}, {"answer": "\"objectively evident to any State dealing with the matter\"", "question": "What is a \"manifest violation\" required?"}, {"answer": "a head of state has acted within his proper authority", "question": "What does a strong presumption exist internationally that a head of state has acted within his proper authority?"}, {"answer": "no", "question": "How many treaties have ever been invalidated on this provision?"}, {"answer": "[citation needed]", "question": "What does a party's consent to a treaty have been invalidated on?"}]
context: A party's consent to a treaty is invalid if it had been given by an agent or body without power to do so under that state's domestic law. States are reluctant to inquire into the internal affairs and processes of other states, and so a "manifest violation" is required such that it would be "objectively evident to any State dealing with the matter". A strong presumption exists internationally that a head of state has acted within his proper authority. It seems that no treaty has ever actually been invalidated on this provision.[citation needed]

qapairs: [{"answer": "if it is given by a representative who ignored restrictions he is subject to by his sovereign during the negotiations", "question": "What happens to a representative who ignored restrictions he is subject to by his sovereign during the negotiations?"}, {"answer": "[citation needed]", "question": "What is the name of the citation needed for a representative who ignored restrictions he is subject to by his sovereign during the negotiations?"}]
context: Consent is also invalid if it is given by a representative who ignored restrictions he is subject to by his sovereign during the negotiations, if the other parties to the treaty were notified of those restrictions prior to his signing.[citation needed]

qapairs: [{"answer": "The Law of Treaties", "question": "What preamble states that treaties are a source of international law?"}, {"answer": "internal law", "question": "What does the law of treaties mean that if an act or lack thereof is condemned under international law, it will not assume international legality even "}, {"answer": "international law", "question": "What will always prevail in case of a conflict with domestic law?"}]
context: According to the preamble in The Law of Treaties, treaties are a source of international law. If an act or lack thereof is condemned under international law, the act will not assume international legality even if approved by internal law. This means that in case of a conflict with domestic law, international law will always prevail.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Articles 46\u201353", "question": "What articles of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties set out the only ways that treaties can be invalidated?"}, {"answer": "the content of the treaty itself", "question": "What is the cause of an invalidation of a treaty?"}, {"answer": "withdrawal, suspension, or termination", "question": "What is invalidation separate from?"}]
context: Articles 46–53 of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties set out the only ways that treaties can be invalidated—considered unenforceable and void under international law. A treaty will be invalidated due to either the circumstances by which a state party joined the treaty, or due to the content of the treaty itself. Invalidation is separate from withdrawal, suspension, or termination (addressed above), which all involve an alteration in the consent of the parties of a previously valid treaty rather than the invalidation of that consent in the first place.

qapairs: [{"answer": "an erroneous understanding of a fact or situation at the time of conclusion", "question": "What formed the \"essential basis\" of the state's consent?"}, {"answer": "the truth", "question": "What should have been evident in a state's consent?"}]
context: A state's consent may be invalidated if there was an erroneous understanding of a fact or situation at the time of conclusion, which formed the "essential basis" of the state's consent. Consent will not be invalidated if the misunderstanding was due to the state's own conduct, or if the truth should have been evident.

qapairs: [{"answer": "fraudulent conduct", "question": "Consent will be invalidated if it was induced by what?"}, {"answer": "the threat or use of force", "question": "What does coercion of a representative, or the state itself use to obtain the consent of that state to a treaty invalidate?"}]
context: Consent will also be invalidated if it was induced by the fraudulent conduct of another party, or by the direct or indirect "corruption" of its representative by another party to the treaty. Coercion of either a representative, or the state itself through the threat or use of force, if used to obtain the consent of that state to a treaty, will invalidate that consent.

qapairs: [{"answer": "null and void", "question": "What is a treaty if it is in violation of a peremptory norm?"}, {"answer": "permitting no violations", "question": "What is a treaty recognized as if it violates a peremptory norm?"}, {"answer": "no state can legally assume an obligation to commit or permit such acts", "question": "What does a treaty mean?"}]
context: A treaty is null and void if it is in violation of a peremptory norm. These norms, unlike other principles of customary law, are recognized as permitting no violations and so cannot be altered through treaty obligations. These are limited to such universally accepted prohibitions as those against the aggressive use of force, genocide and other crimes against humanity, piracy, hostilities directed at civilian population, racial discrimination and apartheid, slavery and torture, meaning that no state can legally assume an obligation to commit or permit such acts.

qapairs: [{"answer": "the International Court of Justice", "question": "What is the judiciary organ of the United Nations Charter?"}, {"answer": "to prevent the proliferation of secret treaties that occurred in the 19th and 20th century", "question": "What was done to prevent the proliferation of secret treaties that occurred in the 19th and 20th century?"}, {"answer": "Section 103", "question": "What section of the Charter states that its members' obligations outweigh any competing obligations under other treaties?"}]
context: The United Nations Charter states that treaties must be registered with the UN to be invoked before it or enforced in its judiciary organ, the International Court of Justice. This was done to prevent the proliferation of secret treaties that occurred in the 19th and 20th century. Section 103 of the Charter also states that its members' obligations under it outweigh any competing obligations under other treaties.

qapairs: [{"answer": "signature, ratification and entry into force", "question": "What are the official legal procedures of the United Nations?"}, {"answer": "Office of Legal Affairs", "question": "Who applies the official legal procedures of the United Nations?"}]
context: After their adoption, treaties as well as their amendments have to follow the official legal procedures of the United Nations, as applied by the Office of Legal Affairs, including signature, ratification and entry into force.

qapairs: [{"answer": "modern treaty law and the historical Articles of Confederation", "question": "What is the difference between the UN and the pre-Constitutional United States Federal government?"}]
context: In function and effectiveness, the UN has been compared to the pre-Constitutional United States Federal government by some[citation needed], giving a comparison between modern treaty law and the historical Articles of Confederation.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Congress", "question": "Who approves a treaty?"}, {"answer": "the executive branch is free to negotiate and sign a treaty", "question": "What is the meaning of a treaty?"}, {"answer": "a presidential decree published in the federal register", "question": "What has the Federal Supreme Court ruled that a treaty must be incorporated into domestic law?"}]
context: The Brazilian federal constitution states that the power to enter into treaties is vested in the president and that such treaties must be approved by Congress (articles 84, clause VIII, and 49, clause I). In practice, this has been interpreted as meaning that the executive branch is free to negotiate and sign a treaty, but its ratification by the president is contingent upon the prior approval of Congress.
