context: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is the domestic intelligence and security service of the United States, which simultaneously serves as the nation's prime federal law enforcement organization. Operating under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Department of Justice, FBI is concurrently a member of the U.S. Intelligence Community and reports to both the Attorney General and the Director of National Intelligence. A leading U.S. counterterrorism, counterintelligence, and criminal investigative organization, FBI has jurisdiction over violations of more than 200 categories of federal crimes.

qapairs: [{"answer": "J. Edgar Hoover", "question": "Who served as Director from 1924 to 1972?"}, {"answer": "Scientific Crime Detection Laboratory", "question": "What was the name of the FBI Laboratory?"}, {"answer": "FBI Laboratory", "question": "What was the name of the Scientific Crime Detection Laboratory?"}, {"answer": "most major cases and projects that the FBI handled during his tenure", "question": "What was Hoover involved in during his tenure?"}, {"answer": "ten years", "question": "How long did Congress limit the tenure of future FBI Directors?"}]
context: J. Edgar Hoover served as Director from 1924 to 1972, a combined 48 years with the BOI, DOI, and FBI. He was chiefly responsible for creating the Scientific Crime Detection Laboratory, or the FBI Laboratory, which officially opened in 1932, as part of his work to professionalize investigations by the government. Hoover was substantially involved in most major cases and projects that the FBI handled during his tenure. After Hoover's death, Congress passed legislation that limited the tenure of future FBI Directors to ten years.

qapairs: [{"answer": "15", "question": "How many sub-offices does the FBI operate in U.S. embassies and consulates?"}, {"answer": "60", "question": "How many Legal Attache offices does the FBI operate?"}, {"answer": "foreign security services", "question": "What is the purpose of the FBI's overseas offices?"}, {"answer": "secret activities overseas", "question": "What does the FBI do at times carry out?"}]
context: Despite its domestic focus, the FBI also maintains a significant international footprint, operating 60 Legal Attache (LEGAT) offices and 15 sub-offices in U.S. embassies and consulates across the globe. These overseas offices exist primarily for the purpose of coordination with foreign security services and do not usually conduct unilateral operations in the host countries. The FBI can and does at times carry out secret activities overseas, just as the CIA has a limited domestic function; these activities generally require coordination across government agencies.

qapairs: [{"answer": "August 25, 1953", "question": "When did the FBI create the Top Hoodlum Program?"}, {"answer": "Washington", "question": "Where did the FBI report information on mobsters in their territories?"}, {"answer": "Prohibition-organized groups", "question": "What was the name of the group that became fronts for crime in major cities and small towns?"}, {"answer": "undercover and from within these organizations", "question": "What did the FBI do to investigate the former Prohibition-organized groups?"}, {"answer": "dismantled many of the groups", "question": "What did the FBI eventually dismantle?"}, {"answer": "National Crime Syndicate", "question": "What organization did Hoover initially deny in the United States?"}, {"answer": "RICO Act", "question": "What Act is still used for all organized crime and individuals who might fall under the RICO Act?"}]
context: In response to organized crime, on August 25, 1953, the FBI created the Top Hoodlum Program. The national office directed field offices to gather information on mobsters in their territories and to report it regularly to Washington for a centralized collection of intelligence on racketeers. After the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO Act, took effect, the FBI began investigating the former Prohibition-organized groups, which had become fronts for crime in major cities and small towns. All of the FBI work was done undercover and from within these organizations, using the provisions provided in the RICO Act. Gradually the agency dismantled many of the groups. Although Hoover initially denied the existence of a National Crime Syndicate in the United States, the Bureau later conducted operations against known organized crime syndicates and families, including those headed by Sam Giancana and John Gotti. The RICO Act is still used today for all organized crime and any individuals who might fall under the Act.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1998", "question": "When did the FBI undergo a technological upgrade?"}, {"answer": "Computer Investigations and Infrastructure Threat Assessment Center", "question": "What is the name of the CITAC?"}, {"answer": "telecommunications advancements", "question": "What changed the nature of such problems?"}]
context: After Congress passed the Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act (CALEA, 1994), the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA, 1996), and the Economic Espionage Act (EEA, 1996), the FBI followed suit and underwent a technological upgrade in 1998, just as it did with its CART team in 1991. Computer Investigations and Infrastructure Threat Assessment Center (CITAC) and the National Infrastructure Protection Center (NIPC) were created to deal with the increase in Internet-related problems, such as computer viruses, worms, and other malicious programs that threatened US operations. With these developments, the FBI increased its electronic surveillance in public safety and national security investigations, adapting to the telecommunications advancements that changed the nature of such problems.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations", "question": "What is the FBI's chief tool against organized crime?"}, {"answer": "United States Department of Justice", "question": "Who prosecutes violations of the RICO Act of 1964?"}, {"answer": "1964", "question": "When was the United States Civil Rights Act passed?"}, {"answer": "Drug Enforcement Administration", "question": "Who does the FBI share concurrent jurisdiction with in the enforcement of the Controlled Substances Act of 1970?"}]
context: The FBI's chief tool against organized crime is the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act. The FBI is also charged with the responsibility of enforcing compliance of the United States Civil Rights Act of 1964 and investigating violations of the act in addition to prosecuting such violations with the United States Department of Justice (DOJ). The FBI also shares concurrent jurisdiction with the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) in the enforcement of the Controlled Substances Act of 1970.

qapairs: [{"answer": "U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP)", "question": "What agencies do the FBI work with in seaport and airport security?"}, {"answer": "Immigration and Customs Enforcement Homeland Security Investigations", "question": "What is the name of the FBI that has the same amount of investigative man power as the FBI?"}, {"answer": "the U.S. Department of Homeland Security", "question": "Who created the FBI?"}, {"answer": "Joint Terrorism Task Force", "question": "The FBI and ICE-HSI are both integral members of what task force?"}]
context: The FBI often works in conjunction with other Federal agencies, including the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) and U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) in seaport and airport security, and the National Transportation Safety Board in investigating airplane crashes and other critical incidents. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Homeland Security Investigations (ICE-HSI) has nearly the same amount of investigative man power as the FBI, and investigates the largest range of crimes. In the wake of the September 11 attacks, then-Attorney General Ashcroft assigned the FBI as the designated lead organization in terrorism investigations after the creation of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. ICE-HSI and the FBI are both integral members of the Joint Terrorism Task Force.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Office of the Director", "question": "What is the FBI's office?"}, {"answer": "executive assistant director", "question": "Who manages each branch?"}, {"answer": "an assistant director", "question": "Who heads each branch of the FBI?"}, {"answer": "deputy assistant directors", "question": "Who leads the divisions of the FBI?"}, {"answer": "section chiefs", "question": "What are the sections of the FBI headed by?"}, {"answer": "special agents", "question": "Section chiefs are ranked analogous to what?"}]
context: The FBI is organized into functional branches and the Office of the Director, which contains most administrative offices. An executive assistant director manages each branch. Each branch is then divided into offices and divisions, each headed by an assistant director. The various divisions are further divided into sub-branches, led by deputy assistant directors. Within these sub-branches there are various sections headed by section chiefs. Section chiefs are ranked analogous to special agents in charge.

qapairs: [{"answer": "J. Edgar Hoover Building", "question": "Where is the FBI headquartered?"}, {"answer": "56", "question": "How many field offices does the FBI have in major cities across the United States?"}, {"answer": "over 400", "question": "How many agencies does the FBI maintain?"}, {"answer": "96 million", "question": "How many sets of fingerprints are stored in Clarksburg, West Virginia?"}, {"answer": "Winchester, Virginia", "question": "Where is the Records Management Division located?"}]
context: The FBI is headquartered at the J. Edgar Hoover Building in Washington, D.C., with 56 field offices in major cities across the United States. The FBI also maintains over 400 resident agencies across the United States, as well as over 50 legal attachés at United States embassies and consulates. Many specialized FBI functions are located at facilities in Quantico, Virginia, as well as a "data campus" in Clarksburg, West Virginia, where 96 million sets of fingerprints "from across the United States are stored, along with others collected by American authorities from prisoners in Saudi Arabia and Yemen, Iraq and Afghanistan." The FBI is in process of moving its Records Management Division, which processes Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, to Winchester, Virginia.

qapairs: [{"answer": "5", "question": "How many cases were wounded?"}, {"answer": "Samuel Walker", "question": "Who was a professor of criminal justice at the University of Nebraska Omaha?"}, {"answer": "150", "question": "How many people were wounded in the same time period?"}, {"answer": "internal investigation", "question": "What investigation found all shootings by FBI agents justified?"}, {"answer": "$1.3 million", "question": "How much did the FBI pay for a bank robber?"}]
context: During the period from 1993 to 2011, FBI agents fired their weapons on 289 occasions; FBI internal reviews found the shots justified in all but 5 cases, in none of the 5 cases were people wounded. Samuel Walker, a professor of criminal justice at the University of Nebraska Omaha said the number of shots found to be unjustified was "suspiciously low." In the same time period, the FBI wounded 150 people, 70 of whom died; the FBI found all 150 shootings to be justified. Likewise, during the period from 2011 to the present, all shootings by FBI agents have been found to be justified by internal investigation. In a 2002 case in Maryland, an innocent man was shot, and later paid $1.3 million by the FBI after agents mistook him for a bank robber; the internal investigation found that the shooting was justified, based on the man's actions.

qapairs: [{"answer": "The local councils", "question": "Who is responsible for providing the functions set out in the Local Government Act 1989?"}, {"answer": "Parliament House in Spring Street", "question": "Where does the Victorian state government govern?"}, {"answer": "public transport, main roads, traffic control, policing, education above preschool level, health and planning of major infrastructure projects", "question": "What are some of the services that are associated with local government in other countries?"}, {"answer": "Melburnian", "question": "What issues often feature prominently in state elections?"}]
context: The local councils are responsible for providing the functions set out in the Local Government Act 1989 such as urban planning and waste management. Most other government services are provided or regulated by the Victorian state government, which governs from Parliament House in Spring Street. These include services which are associated with local government in other countries and include public transport, main roads, traffic control, policing, education above preschool level, health and planning of major infrastructure projects. The state government retains the right to override certain local government decisions, including urban planning, and Melburnian issues often feature prominently in state election.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1 January 1901", "question": "When did Melbourne become the seat of government of the federation?"}, {"answer": "1927", "question": "When was Melbourne moved to Canberra?"}, {"answer": "Royal Exhibition Building", "question": "Where was the first federal parliament convened?"}, {"answer": "1930", "question": "When did the Governor-General reside at Government House in Melbourne?"}]
context: At the time of Australia's federation on 1 January 1901, Melbourne became the seat of government of the federation. The first federal parliament was convened on 9 May 1901 in the Royal Exhibition Building, subsequently moving to the Victorian Parliament House where it was located until 1927, when it was moved to Canberra. The Governor-General of Australia resided at Government House in Melbourne until 1930 and many major national institutions remained in Melbourne well into the twentieth century.

qapairs: [{"answer": "uncertain", "question": "What was the nature of government under the Angevin monarchs?"}, {"answer": "vis et voluntas", "question": "What principle did John's predecessors rule using?"}, {"answer": "imperial status", "question": "What did John claim for himself as ruler?"}, {"answer": "the 12th century", "question": "In what century were contrary opinions expressed about the nature of kingship?"}, {"answer": "if a king refused to do so", "question": "What was there no model for?"}, {"answer": "he had taken council with the barons", "question": "What did John justify his actions on the basis of?"}, {"answer": "a case of \"royal schizophrenia\" in his approach to government", "question": "What did modern historians think John suffered from in his approach to government?"}]
context: The nature of government under the Angevin monarchs was ill-defined and uncertain. John's predecessors had ruled using the principle of vis et voluntas, or "force and will", taking executive and sometimes arbitrary decisions, often justified on the basis that a king was above the law. Both Henry II and Richard had argued that kings possessed a quality of "divine majesty"; John continued this trend and claimed an "almost imperial status" for himself as ruler. During the 12th century, there were contrary opinions expressed about the nature of kingship, and many contemporary writers believed that monarchs should rule in accordance with the custom and the law, and take counsel of the leading members of the realm. There was as yet no model for what should happen if a king refused to do so. Despite his claim to unique authority within England, John would sometimes justify his actions on the basis that he had taken council with the barons. Modern historians remain divided as to whether John suffered from a case of "royal schizophrenia" in his approach to government, or if his actions merely reflected the complex model of Angevin kingship in the early 13th century.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Valencia", "question": "Where did Ferdinand go?"}, {"answer": "General Elio", "question": "Who invited the King to reclaim his absolute rights?"}, {"answer": "1812", "question": "When did the king abolish the Constitution?"}, {"answer": "10 May", "question": "When did the king dissolve the two chambers of the Spanish Parliament?"}, {"answer": "Trienio Liberal", "question": "When was the constitution reinstated?"}]
context: Ferdinand refused and went to Valencia instead of Madrid. Here, on 17 April, General Elio invited the King to reclaim his absolute rights and put his troops at the King's disposition. The king abolished the Constitution of 1812. He followed this act by dissolving the two chambers of the Spanish Parliament on 10 May. Thus began six years (1814–1820) of absolutist rule, but the constitution was reinstated during the Trienio Liberal, a period of three years of liberal government in Spain from 1820–1823.

qapairs: [{"answer": "United States", "question": "What country was Eritrea federated with Ethiopia?"}, {"answer": "the Emperor", "question": "Who did the resolution call for Eritrea and Ethiopia to be linked through a loose federal structure?"}, {"answer": "its own flag", "question": "What was Eritrea's administrative and judicial structure?"}, {"answer": "foreign affairs", "question": "What did the federal government control?"}, {"answer": "independence", "question": "What did the resolution ignore the wishes of Eritreans?"}]
context: Following the adoption of UN Resolution 390A(V) in December 1950, Eritrea was federated with Ethiopia under the prompting of the United States. The resolution called for Eritrea and Ethiopia to be linked through a loose federal structure under the sovereignty of the Emperor. Eritrea was to have its own administrative and judicial structure, its own flag, and control over its domestic affairs, including police, local administration, and taxation. The federal government, which for all intents and purposes was the existing imperial government, was to control foreign affairs (including commerce), defense, finance, and transportation. The resolution ignored the wishes of Eritreans for independence, but guaranteed the population democratic rights and a measure of autonomy.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Suez crisis", "question": "Which crisis led to the first major personal criticism of the Queen?"}, {"answer": "Lord Altrincham", "question": "Who accused the Queen of being \"out of touch\" in a magazine?"}, {"answer": "public figures", "question": "Who denounced Lord Altrincham?"}, {"answer": "Macmillan", "question": "Who advised the Queen to appoint the Earl of Home as prime minister?"}, {"answer": "Earl of Home", "question": "Who did Macmillan advise the Queen to appoint as prime minister?"}, {"answer": "a small number of ministers or a single minister", "question": "How many ministers did the Queen appoint the prime minister?"}, {"answer": "1965", "question": "When did the Conservatives adopt a formal mechanism for electing a leader?"}]
context: The Suez crisis and the choice of Eden's successor led in 1957 to the first major personal criticism of the Queen. In a magazine, which he owned and edited, Lord Altrincham accused her of being "out of touch". Altrincham was denounced by public figures and slapped by a member of the public appalled by his comments. Six years later, in 1963, Macmillan resigned and advised the Queen to appoint the Earl of Home as prime minister, advice that she followed. The Queen again came under criticism for appointing the prime minister on the advice of a small number of ministers or a single minister. In 1965, the Conservatives adopted a formal mechanism for electing a leader, thus relieving her of involvement.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Gough Whitlam", "question": "Who was the Australian Prime Minister at the height of the 1975 Australian constitutional crisis?"}, {"answer": "Governor-General Sir John Kerr", "question": "Who dismissed Gough Whitlam?"}, {"answer": "Speaker Gordon Scholes", "question": "Who appealed to the Queen to reverse Kerr's decision?"}, {"answer": "she would not interfere in decisions reserved by the Constitution of Australia for the governor-general", "question": "What did Scholes say Whitlam would not interfere with?"}, {"answer": "The crisis fuelled Australian republicanism", "question": "What was the cause of the Australian constitutional crisis?"}]
context: A year later, at the height of the 1975 Australian constitutional crisis, the Australian Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, was dismissed from his post by Governor-General Sir John Kerr, after the Opposition-controlled Senate rejected Whitlam's budget proposals. As Whitlam had a majority in the House of Representatives, Speaker Gordon Scholes appealed to the Queen to reverse Kerr's decision. She declined, stating that she would not interfere in decisions reserved by the Constitution of Australia for the governor-general. The crisis fuelled Australian republicanism.

qapairs: [{"answer": "the Queen", "question": "Who was responsible for choosing a leader after Eden's resignation?"}, {"answer": "Lord Salisbury", "question": "Who was the Lord President of the Council?"}, {"answer": "Lord President of the Council", "question": "Who was Lord Salisbury?"}, {"answer": "Harold Macmillan", "question": "Who was the Queen's recommended candidate?"}]
context: The absence of a formal mechanism within the Conservative Party for choosing a leader meant that, following Eden's resignation, it fell to the Queen to decide whom to commission to form a government. Eden recommended that she consult Lord Salisbury, the Lord President of the Council. Lord Salisbury and Lord Kilmuir, the Lord Chancellor, consulted the British Cabinet, Winston Churchill, and the Chairman of the backbench 1922 Committee, resulting in the Queen appointing their recommended candidate: Harold Macmillan.

qapairs: [{"answer": "February 1974", "question": "When did Edward Heath advise the Queen to call a general election?"}, {"answer": "Austronesian Pacific Rim", "question": "Where did Edward Heath advise the Queen to call a general election?"}, {"answer": "hung parliament", "question": "What was the result of the general election?"}, {"answer": "Harold Wilson", "question": "Who was the Leader of the Opposition?"}]
context: In February 1974, the British Prime Minister, Edward Heath, advised the Queen to call a general election in the middle of her tour of the Austronesian Pacific Rim, requiring her to fly back to Britain. The election resulted in a hung parliament; Heath's Conservatives were not the largest party, but could stay in office if they formed a coalition with the Liberals. Heath only resigned when discussions on forming a coalition foundered, after which the Queen asked the Leader of the Opposition, Labour's Harold Wilson, to form a government.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Blair", "question": "Who was the British Prime Minister?"}, {"answer": "Iraq and Afghanistan", "question": "Where was the British Armed Forces overstretched?"}, {"answer": "peace", "question": "What did the Queen admire Blair's efforts to achieve in Northern Ireland?"}, {"answer": "20 March 2008", "question": "When was the first Maundy service held outside England and Wales?"}, {"answer": "Mary McAleese", "question": "Who invited the Queen to visit the Republic of Ireland in May 2011?"}]
context: In May 2007, The Daily Telegraph, citing unnamed sources, reported that the Queen was "exasperated and frustrated" by the policies of the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, that she was concerned the British Armed Forces were overstretched in Iraq and Afghanistan, and that she had raised concerns over rural and countryside issues with Blair. She was, however, said to admire Blair's efforts to achieve peace in Northern Ireland. On 20 March 2008, at the Church of Ireland St Patrick's Cathedral, Armagh, the Queen attended the first Maundy service held outside England and Wales. At the invitation of the Irish President, Mary McAleese, the Queen made the first state visit to the Republic of Ireland by a British monarch in May 2011.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Gary Gilmore", "question": "Who was shot by firing squad in Utah?"}, {"answer": "John Spenkelink", "question": "Who was electrocution of the electric chair after the moratorium?"}, {"answer": "Jesse Bishop", "question": "Who was the first use of the gas chamber after the moratorium?"}, {"answer": "Westley Allan Dodd", "question": "Who was the first use of the gallows after the moratorium?"}, {"answer": "December 7, 1982", "question": "When was the first use of lethal injection?"}]
context: The moratorium ended on January 17, 1977 with the shooting of Gary Gilmore by firing squad in Utah. The first use of the electric chair after the moratorium was the electrocution of John Spenkelink in Florida on May 25, 1979. The first use of the gas chamber after the moratorium was the gassing of Jesse Bishop in Nevada on October 22, 1979. The first use of the gallows after the moratorium was the hanging of Westley Allan Dodd in Washington on January 5, 1993. The first use of lethal injection was on December 7, 1982, when Charles Brooks, Jr., was executed in Texas.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Electrocution", "question": "What was the preferred method of execution during the 20th century?"}, {"answer": "Old Sparky", "question": "What are electric chairs commonly nicknamed?"}, {"answer": "malfunctions", "question": "What caused discussion of their cruelty and resulted in a shift to lethal injection as the preferred method of execution?"}, {"answer": "lethal injection", "question": "What dominates as a method of execution?"}]
context: Electrocution was the preferred method of execution during the 20th century. Electric chairs have commonly been nicknamed Old Sparky; however, Alabama's electric chair became known as the "Yellow Mama" due to its unique color. Some, particularly in Florida, were noted for malfunctions, which caused discussion of their cruelty and resulted in a shift to lethal injection as the preferred method of execution. Although lethal injection dominates as a method of execution, some states allow prisoners on death row to choose the method used to execute them.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Rhode Island", "question": "What state had a long history of no death penalty?"}, {"answer": "1957", "question": "When was the death penalty last used?"}, {"answer": "1978", "question": "In what year did Oregon abolish the death penalty?"}]
context: Other states with long histories of no death penalty include Wisconsin (the only state with only one execution), Rhode Island (although later reintroduced, it was unused and abolished again), Maine, North Dakota, Minnesota, West Virginia, Iowa, and Vermont. The District of Columbia has also abolished the death penalty; it was last used in 1957. Oregon abolished the death penalty through an overwhelming majority in a 1964 public referendum but reinstated it in a 1984 joint death penalty/life imprisonment referendum by an even higher margin after a similar 1978 referendum succeeded but was not implemented due to judicial rulings.

qapairs: [{"answer": "700", "question": "How many murders have been committed in recent years?"}, {"answer": "1", "question": "How many executions are there for every 325 murder convictions?"}, {"answer": "32", "question": "How many of the 50 states still execute people?"}, {"answer": "Alabama", "question": "Which state has the highest per capita rate of death sentences?"}, {"answer": "judges", "question": "Who overrides life imprisonment sentences?"}, {"answer": "No other states allow this", "question": "What does Alabama have the highest per capita rate of death sentences?"}]
context: Within the context of the overall murder rate, the death penalty cannot be said to be widely or routinely used in the United States; in recent years the average has been about one execution for about every 700 murders committed, or 1 execution for about every 325 murder convictions. However, 32 of the 50 states still execute people. Among them, Alabama has the highest per capita rate of death sentences. This is due to judges overriding life imprisonment sentences and imposing the death penalty. No other states allow this.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Michigan", "question": "What state does Puerto Rico have a constitutional prohibition on capital punishment?"}, {"answer": "federal government", "question": "Who is responsible for capital punishment in Puerto Rico?"}]
context: Puerto Rico's constitution expressly forbids capital punishment, stating "The death penalty shall not exist", setting it apart from all U.S. states and territories other than Michigan, which also has a constitutional prohibition (eleven other states and the District of Columbia have abolished capital punishment through statutory law). However, capital punishment is still applicable to offenses committed in Puerto Rico, if they fall under the jurisdiction of the federal government, though federal death penalty prosecutions there have generated significant controversy.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Furman v. Georgia", "question": "What case was the Supreme Court's decision in?"}, {"answer": "1972", "question": "When was capital punishment suspended in the United States?"}, {"answer": "1976", "question": "When was capital punishment suspended in the United States?"}, {"answer": "June 2, 1967", "question": "When was Luis Monge executed?"}, {"answer": "Luis Monge", "question": "Who was the last pre-Furman execution?"}, {"answer": "Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution", "question": "What was the reason for the death penalty being imposed in violation of the Supreme Court's decision in Furman v. Georgia?"}, {"answer": "per se unconstitutional", "question": "What has the Supreme Court never ruled the death penalty to be?"}]
context: Capital punishment was suspended in the United States from 1972 through 1976 primarily as a result of the Supreme Court's decision in Furman v. Georgia. The last pre-Furman execution was that of Luis Monge on June 2, 1967. In this case, the court found that the death penalty was being imposed in an unconstitutional manner, on the grounds of cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution. The Supreme Court has never ruled the death penalty to be per se unconstitutional.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1976", "question": "In what year was Gregg v. Georgia bifurcated into guilt-innocence and sentencing phases?"}, {"answer": "first-degree murder", "question": "If the defendant is innocent or otherwise not convicted of what?"}, {"answer": "death or life in prison", "question": "What is the ultimate penalty?"}]
context: In 1976, contemporaneously with Woodson and Roberts, the Court decided Gregg v. Georgia and upheld a procedure in which the trial of capital crimes was bifurcated into guilt-innocence and sentencing phases. At the first proceeding, the jury decides the defendant's guilt; if the defendant is innocent or otherwise not convicted of first-degree murder, the death penalty will not be imposed. At the second hearing, the jury determines whether certain statutory aggravating factors exist, whether any mitigating factors exist, and, in many jurisdictions, weigh the aggravating and mitigating factors in assessing the ultimate penalty – either death or life in prison, either with or without parole.

qapairs: [{"answer": "98", "question": "How many executions did the Temporary Temporary Temporary Temporary Temporary Temporary Temporary Temporary Tempo"}, {"answer": "1976", "question": "When was the death penalty reauthorized?"}, {"answer": "over one-third", "question": "How much of modern executions are in Texas?"}, {"answer": "California", "question": "Which state has the highest number of prisoners on death row?"}]
context: Possibly in part due to expedited federal habeas corpus procedures embodied in the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, the pace of executions picked up, reaching a peak of 98 in 1999 and then they declined gradually to 28 in 2015. Since the death penalty was reauthorized in 1976, 1,411 people have been executed, almost exclusively by the states, with most occurring after 1990. Texas has accounted for over one-third of modern executions (although only two death sentences were imposed in Texas during 2015, with the courts preferring to issue sentences of life without parole instead) and over four times as many as Oklahoma, the state with the second-highest number. California has the greatest number of prisoners on death row, has issued the highest number of death sentences but has held relatively few executions.

qapairs: [{"answer": "November 2008", "question": "When did only one person on death row have been convicted of murder?"}, {"answer": "Demarcus Sears", "question": "Who remains under a death sentence in Georgia for the crime of \"kidnapping with bodily injury\"?"}, {"answer": "Gloria Ann Wilbur", "question": "Who was the victim of Demarcus Sears?"}, {"answer": "1986", "question": "When was Demarcus Sears convicted?"}, {"answer": "Kentucky", "question": "Where was Gloria Ann Wilbur murdered?"}, {"answer": "a jury in Georgia", "question": "Who sentenced Demarcus Sears to death for \"kidnapping with bodily injury\"?"}]
context: As of November 2008, there is only one person on death row facing capital punishment who has not been convicted of murder. Demarcus Sears remains under a death sentence in Georgia for the crime of "kidnapping with bodily injury." Sears was convicted in 1986 for the kidnapping and bodily injury of victim Gloria Ann Wilbur. Wilbur was kidnapped and beaten in Georgia, raped in Tennessee, and murdered in Kentucky. Sears was never charged with the murder of Wilbur in Kentucky, but was sentenced to death by a jury in Georgia for "kidnapping with bodily injury."

qapairs: [{"answer": "final", "question": "When a death sentence is affirmed on direct review, it is considered what?"}, {"answer": "supplemental methods to attack the judgment", "question": "What is less familiar than a typical appeal?"}, {"answer": "collateral review", "question": "What is an avenue for upsetting judgments that have become otherwise final?"}, {"answer": "state collateral review", "question": "What is the first step in collateral review?"}, {"answer": "direct review", "question": "When a death sentence is affirmed on a state level trial, it proceeds immediately from what to federal habeas corpus?"}, {"answer": "state to state", "question": "How does the process of collateral review vary from state to state?"}, {"answer": "to permit the prisoner to challenge his sentence on grounds that could not have been raised reasonably at trial or on direct review", "question": "What is the purpose of collateral proceedings?"}, {"answer": "ineffective assistance of counsel", "question": "What type of claim requires the court to consider new evidence outside the original trial record?"}, {"answer": "State collateral review", "question": "What helps define the scope of subsequent review through federal habeas corpus?"}, {"answer": "6 percent", "question": "How many death sentences are overturned on state collateral review?"}, {"answer": "53", "question": "How many inmates were overturned in 2010?"}]
context: At times when a death sentence is affirmed on direct review, it is considered final. Yet, supplemental methods to attack the judgment, though less familiar than a typical appeal, do remain. These supplemental remedies are considered collateral review, that is, an avenue for upsetting judgments that have become otherwise final. Where the prisoner received his death sentence in a state-level trial, as is usually the case, the first step in collateral review is state collateral review. (If the case is a federal death penalty case, it proceeds immediately from direct review to federal habeas corpus.) Although all states have some type of collateral review, the process varies widely from state to state. Generally, the purpose of these collateral proceedings is to permit the prisoner to challenge his sentence on grounds that could not have been raised reasonably at trial or on direct review. Most often these are claims, such as ineffective assistance of counsel, which requires the court to consider new evidence outside the original trial record, something courts may not do in an ordinary appeal. State collateral review, though an important step in that it helps define the scope of subsequent review through federal habeas corpus, is rarely successful in and of itself. Only around 6 percent of death sentences are overturned on state collateral review. In 2010, the death sentences of 53 inmates were overturned as a result of legal appeals or high court reversals.

qapairs: [{"answer": "habeas corpus", "question": "What is the only vehicle by which a state prisoner can challenge his judgment of death?"}, {"answer": "Eighth Amendment", "question": "In 2006, the United States Supreme Court approved the use of Section 1983 as a vehicle for challenging a state's method of execution as cruel and"}, {"answer": "the means by which that the judgment will be carried out", "question": "What is the theory that a prisoner bringing such a challenge is not attacking directly his judgment of death?"}, {"answer": "Section 1983", "question": "What did the Supreme Court rule that a prisoner can use instead of habeas corpus to bring the lawsuit?"}, {"answer": "Clarence Hill", "question": "Who's case shows that lower federal courts have often refused to hear suits challenging methods of execution on the ground that the prisoner brought the claim too late"}, {"answer": "Baze v. Rees", "question": "What case affirmed a lethal injection method used by many states?"}]
context: Traditionally, Section 1983 was of limited use for a state prisoner under sentence of death because the Supreme Court has held that habeas corpus, not Section 1983, is the only vehicle by which a state prisoner can challenge his judgment of death. In the 2006 Hill v. McDonough case, however, the United States Supreme Court approved the use of Section 1983 as a vehicle for challenging a state's method of execution as cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment. The theory is that a prisoner bringing such a challenge is not attacking directly his judgment of death, but rather the means by which that the judgment will be carried out. Therefore, the Supreme Court held in the Hill case that a prisoner can use Section 1983 rather than habeas corpus to bring the lawsuit. Yet, as Clarence Hill's own case shows, lower federal courts have often refused to hear suits challenging methods of execution on the ground that the prisoner brought the claim too late and only for the purposes of delay. Further, the Court's decision in Baze v. Rees, upholding a lethal injection method used by many states, has drastically narrowed the opportunity for relief through Section 1983.

qapairs: [{"answer": "38", "question": "How many American Indians were convicted of murder and rape during the Dakota War of 1862?"}, {"answer": "December 26, 1862", "question": "When were the 38 American Indians executed simultaneously?"}, {"answer": "axe", "question": "What blow cut the rope that held the large four-sided platform?"}, {"answer": "the Houston Riot of 1917", "question": "What was the second largest mass execution in the United States history?"}, {"answer": "1723", "question": "When did the largest non-military mass execution occur?"}]
context: The largest single execution in United States history was the hanging of 38 American Indians convicted of murder and rape during the Dakota War of 1862. They were executed simultaneously on December 26, 1862, in Mankato, Minnesota. A single blow from an axe cut the rope that held the large four-sided platform, and the prisoners (except for one whose rope had broken and who had to be re-hanged) fell to their deaths. The second-largest mass execution was also a hanging: the execution of 13 African-American soldiers for taking part in the Houston Riot of 1917. The largest non-military mass execution occurred in one of the original thirteen colonies in 1723, when 26 convicted pirates were hanged in Newport, Rhode Island by order of the Admiralty Court.

qapairs: [{"answer": "federal habeas corpus", "question": "What is a unique type of lawsuit that can be brought in federal courts?"}, {"answer": "federal", "question": "What court does federal habeas corpus allow state prisoners to attack a death sentence?"}, {"answer": "1996", "question": "What year was the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act governed by?"}, {"answer": "evidence of innocence must be truly compelling", "question": "What must be a valid defense at this late stage of the process?"}]
context: After a death sentence is affirmed in state collateral review, the prisoner may file for federal habeas corpus, which is a unique type of lawsuit that can be brought in federal courts. Federal habeas corpus is a species of collateral review, and it is the only way that state prisoners may attack a death sentence in federal court (other than petitions for certiorari to the United States Supreme Court after both direct review and state collateral review). The scope of federal habeas corpus is governed by the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, which restricted significantly its previous scope. The purpose of federal habeas corpus is to ensure that state courts, through the process of direct review and state collateral review, have done at least a reasonable job in protecting the prisoner's federal constitutional rights. Prisoners may also use federal habeas corpus suits to bring forth new evidence that they are innocent of the crime, though to be a valid defense at this late stage in the process, evidence of innocence must be truly compelling.

qapairs: [{"answer": "New Jersey and Illinois", "question": "Where did all death row inmates have their sentences commuted to life in prison without parole when the death penalty repeal bills were signed into law?"}, {"answer": "Governor Martin O'Malley", "question": "Who commuted the state's four remaining death sentences to life in prison without parole in January 2015?"}, {"answer": "State v. Santiago", "question": "In what case did the Connecticut Supreme Court rule that the legislature's decision to abolish capital punishment rendered it an offense to \"evolving standards of de"}, {"answer": "Nebraska", "question": "Which state has ten death row inmates who may still be executed despite abolition?"}]
context: In New Jersey and Illinois, all death row inmates had their sentences commuted to life in prison without parole when the death penalty repeal bills were signed into law. In Maryland, Governor Martin O'Malley commuted the state's four remaining death sentences to life in prison without parole in January 2015. While the bill repealing capital punishment in Connecticut was not retroactive, the Connecticut Supreme Court ruled in 2015 in State v. Santiago that the legislature's decision to prospectively abolish capital punishment rendered it an offense to "evolving standards of decency," thus commuting the sentences of the 11 men remaining on death row to life in prison without parole. New Mexico may yet execute two condemned inmates sentenced prior to abolition, and Nebraska has ten death row inmates who may still be executed despite abolition.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Eighth", "question": "How many Amendment rights do the Supreme Court in Penry v. Lynaugh and Bigby v. Dretke have violated?"}, {"answer": "Penry v. Lynaugh", "question": "In what case did the United States Supreme Court rule that jury instructions in death penalty cases violate the Eighth Amendment rights?"}, {"answer": "specific explanations to the jury", "question": "What does the ruling suggest are necessary to weigh mitigating factors?"}]
context: The United States Supreme Court in Penry v. Lynaugh and the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Bigby v. Dretke have been clear in their decisions that jury instructions in death penalty cases that do not ask about mitigating factors regarding the defendant's mental health violate the defendant's Eighth Amendment rights, saying that the jury is to be instructed to consider mitigating factors when answering unrelated questions. This ruling suggests that specific explanations to the jury are necessary to weigh mitigating factors.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Michigan", "question": "Which state abolished capital punishment shortly after entering the Union?"}, {"answer": "1938", "question": "When did the United States execute Tony Chebatoris at the Federal Correctional Institution?"}, {"answer": "1963", "question": "When was Michigan's fourth constitution ratified?"}, {"answer": "Attempts to change the provision", "question": "What has failed?"}, {"answer": "2004", "question": "When did a constitutional amendment to allow capital punishment fail to make it on the November ballot?"}]
context: Several states have never had capital punishment, the first being Michigan, which abolished it shortly after entering the Union. (However, the United States government executed Tony Chebatoris at the Federal Correctional Institution in Milan, Michigan in 1938.) Article 4, Section 46 of Michigan's fourth Constitution (ratified in 1963; effective in 1964) prohibits any law providing for the penalty of death. Attempts to change the provision have failed. In 2004, a constitutional amendment proposed to allow capital punishment in some circumstances failed to make it on the November ballot after a resolution failed in the legislature and a public initiative failed to gather enough signatures.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994", "question": "What is the method of execution of federal prisoners for offenses under?"}, {"answer": "the judge must choose a state with the death penalty for carrying out the execution", "question": "If the state has no death penalty, what must the judge choose a state with the death penalty for carrying out the execution?"}, {"answer": "lethal injection", "question": "What is the method of execution for offenses under the Drug Kingpin Act of 1988?"}, {"answer": "Drug Kingpin Act of 1988", "question": "In what Act did the execution of federal prisoners take place?"}, {"answer": "Terre Haute, Indiana", "question": "Where is the Federal Correctional Complex located?"}, {"answer": "post-Gregg", "question": "Where has the Federal Correctional Complex been used for federal executions?"}, {"answer": "June 2001", "question": "When were Timothy McVeigh and Juan Garza put to death?"}]
context: The method of execution of federal prisoners for offenses under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is that of the state in which the conviction took place. If the state has no death penalty, the judge must choose a state with the death penalty for carrying out the execution. For offenses under the Drug Kingpin Act of 1988, the method of execution is lethal injection. The Federal Correctional Complex in Terre Haute, Indiana is currently the home of the only death chamber for federal death penalty recipients in the United States, where inmates are put to death by lethal injection. The complex has so far been the only location used for federal executions post-Gregg. Timothy McVeigh and Juan Garza were put to death in June 2001, and Louis Jones, Jr. was put to death on March 18, 2003.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1962", "question": "When did the American Law Institute vote to disavow the framework for capital punishment?"}, {"answer": "Model Penal Code", "question": "What did the American Law Institute vote to disavow the framework for capital punishment?"}, {"answer": "systemic fairness", "question": "What did the study commissioned by the American Law Institute say could not be reconciled?"}]
context: In October 2009, the American Law Institute voted to disavow the framework for capital punishment that it had created in 1962, as part of the Model Penal Code, "in light of the current intractable institutional and structural obstacles to ensuring a minimally adequate system for administering capital punishment." A study commissioned by the institute had said that experience had proved that the goal of individualized decisions about who should be executed and the goal of systemic fairness for minorities and others could not be reconciled.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1977", "question": "In what year was the Coker v. Georgia decision barred the death penalty for rape of an adult woman?"}, {"answer": "the United States", "question": "Where was the death penalty for rape of an adult phased out?"}, {"answer": "three", "question": "How many states maintained the death penalty for child rape?"}, {"answer": "Kennedy v. Louisiana", "question": "Which decision barred the death penalty for child rape in 2008?"}, {"answer": "the defendant took the life of another human being", "question": "What did the Kennedy v. Louisiana decision restrict the death penalty for child rape in the United States?"}, {"answer": "if the victim dies in the perpetrator's custody", "question": "What does the current federal kidnapping statute apply to the death penalty?"}, {"answer": "non-murder offenses", "question": "What type of offenses does the federal government retain the death penalty?"}]
context: In 1977, the Supreme Court's Coker v. Georgia decision barred the death penalty for rape of an adult woman, and implied that the death penalty was inappropriate for any offense against another person other than murder. Prior to the decision, the death penalty for rape of an adult had been gradually phased out in the United States, and at the time of the decision, the State of Georgia and the U.S. Federal government were the only two jurisdictions to still retain the death penalty for that offense. However, three states maintained the death penalty for child rape, as the Coker decision only imposed a ban on executions for the rape of an adult woman. In 2008, the Kennedy v. Louisiana decision barred the death penalty for child rape. The result of these two decisions means that the death penalty in the United States is largely restricted to cases where the defendant took the life of another human being. The current federal kidnapping statute, however, may be exempt because the death penalty applies if the victim dies in the perpetrator's custody, not necessarily by his hand, thus stipulating a resulting death, which was the wording of the objection. In addition, the Federal government retains the death penalty for non-murder offenses that are considered crimes against the state, including treason, espionage, and crimes under military jurisdiction.

qapairs: [{"answer": "espionage", "question": "What type of capital crime is the use of a weapon of mass destruction resulting in death?"}, {"answer": "terrorism", "question": "What is another capital crime?"}]
context: Other capital crimes include: the use of a weapon of mass destruction resulting in death, espionage, terrorism, certain violations of the Geneva Conventions that result in the death of one or more persons, and treason at the federal level; aggravated rape in Louisiana, Florida, and Oklahoma; extortionate kidnapping in Oklahoma; aggravated kidnapping in Georgia, Idaho, Kentucky and South Carolina; aircraft hijacking in Alabama and Mississippi; assault by an escaping capital felon in Colorado; armed robbery in Georgia; drug trafficking resulting in a person's death in Florida; train wrecking which leads to a person's death, and perjury which leads to a person's death in California, Colorado, Idaho and Nebraska.

qapairs: [{"answer": "five-to-four", "question": "How many cases were struck down as unconstitutional?"}, {"answer": "a short statement", "question": "What did the majority of the justices agree on?"}, {"answer": "Byron White and Potter Stewart", "question": "Who expressed concerns about the inconsistent application of the death penalty across a variety of cases?"}, {"answer": "racial discrimination", "question": "What did Stewart and Douglas worry about in enforcement of the death penalty?"}, {"answer": "Eighth Amendment", "question": "What amendment proscribed the death penalty as \"cruel and unusual\" punishment?"}]
context: In a five-to-four decision, the Supreme Court struck down the impositions of the death penalty in each of the consolidated cases as unconstitutional. The five justices in the majority did not produce a common opinion or rationale for their decision, however, and agreed only on a short statement announcing the result. The narrowest opinions, those of Byron White and Potter Stewart, expressed generalized concerns about the inconsistent application of the death penalty across a variety of cases but did not exclude the possibility of a constitutional death penalty law. Stewart and William O. Douglas worried explicitly about racial discrimination in enforcement of the death penalty. Thurgood Marshall and William J. Brennan, Jr. expressed the opinion that the death penalty was proscribed absolutely by the Eighth Amendment as "cruel and unusual" punishment.

qapairs: [{"answer": "156", "question": "How many prisoners have been acquitted or received pardons or commutations on the basis of possible innocence?"}, {"answer": "those exonerated in law", "question": "What does the statistic refer to?"}, {"answer": "Statistics", "question": "Who understates the actual problem of wrongful convictions?"}]
context: In total, 156 prisoners have been either acquitted, or received pardons or commutations on the basis of possible innocence, between 1973 to 2015. Death penalty opponents often argue that this statistic shows how perilously close states have come to undertaking wrongful executions; proponents point out that the statistic refers only to those exonerated in law, and that the truly innocent may be a smaller number. Statistics likely understate the actual problem of wrongful convictions because once an execution has occurred there is often insufficient motivation and finance to keep a case open, and it becomes unlikely at that point that the miscarriage of justice will ever be exposed.

qapairs: [{"answer": "jurisdictions", "question": "Where is the death penalty more often applied?"}, {"answer": "2.5", "question": "How many murderers nationwide were sentenced to the death penalty?"}, {"answer": "2", "question": "How many percent of murderers were given a death sentence in Texas?"}, {"answer": "40", "question": "How many percent of those sentenced were executed by Texas?"}, {"answer": "1 percent", "question": "How much of the sentenced murderers were executed by California?"}]
context: The death penalty is sought and applied more often in some jurisdictions, not only between states but within states. A 2004 Cornell University study showed that while 2.5 percent of murderers convicted nationwide were sentenced to the death penalty, in Nevada 6 percent were given the death penalty. Texas gave 2 percent of murderers a death sentence, less than the national average. Texas, however, executed 40 percent of those sentenced, which was about four times higher than the national average. California had executed only 1 percent of those sentenced.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Congress", "question": "Who passed the Drug Kingpin Act of 1988 and the Federal Death Penalty Act of 1994?"}, {"answer": "Drug Kingpin Act of 1988 and the Federal Death Penalty Act of 1994", "question": "What Act made roughly fifty crimes punishable by death?"}, {"answer": "treason, espionage (spying for another country), and high-level drug trafficking", "question": "What are some non-death capital offenses?"}, {"answer": "their constitutionality", "question": "What has the Supreme Court not ruled on?"}]
context: Congress acted defiantly toward the Supreme Court by passing the Drug Kingpin Act of 1988 and the Federal Death Penalty Act of 1994 that made roughly fifty crimes punishable by death, including crimes that do not always involve the death of someone. Such non-death capital offenses include treason, espionage (spying for another country), and high-level drug trafficking. Since no one has yet been sentenced to death for such non-death capital offenses, the Supreme Court has not ruled on their constitutionality.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Richard Dieter", "question": "Who was the director of the Death Penalty Information Center?"}, {"answer": "Troy Davis", "question": "Who was executed in 2011?"}, {"answer": "passion", "question": "What did Dieter say people weren't expecting from people in opposition to the death penalty?"}, {"answer": "loud and clear", "question": "What was the message that many people are not happy with the execution of Troy Davis?"}, {"answer": "Amnesty International", "question": "Who led the campaign to spare Davis's life?"}, {"answer": "renewed energy", "question": "What did Brian Evans predict the debate will be conducted with?"}]
context: After the September 2011 execution of Troy Davis, believed by many to be innocent, Richard Dieter, the director of the Death Penalty Information Center, said this case was a clear wake-up call to politicians across the United States. He said: "They weren't expecting such passion from people in opposition to the death penalty. There's a widely held perception that all Americans are united in favor of executions, but this message came across loud and clear that many people are not happy with it." Brian Evans of Amnesty International, which led the campaign to spare Davis's life, said that there was a groundswell in America of people "who are tired of a justice system that is inhumane and inflexible and allows executions where there is clear doubts about guilt". He predicted the debate would now be conducted with renewed energy.

qapairs: [{"answer": "complex", "question": "What is the legal administration of the death penalty in the United States?"}, {"answer": "four", "question": "How many critical steps does the legal administration of the death penalty involve?"}, {"answer": "Section 1983 challenge", "question": "What is the final fifth level of process that has become increasingly important?"}, {"answer": "executive", "question": "What is pardon?"}, {"answer": "1995\u20131996", "question": "When was the number of new death sentences handed down?"}, {"answer": "73", "question": "How many new death sentences were handed down in 2014?"}]
context: The legal administration of the death penalty in the United States is complex. Typically, it involves four critical steps: (1) sentencing, (2) direct review, (3) state collateral review, and (4) federal habeas corpus. Recently, a narrow and final fifth level of process – (5) the Section 1983 challenge – has become increasingly important. (Clemency or pardon, through which the Governor or President of the jurisdiction can unilaterally reduce or abrogate a death sentence, is an executive rather than judicial process.) The number of new death sentences handed down peaked in 1995–1996 (309). There were 73 new death sentences handed down in 2014, the lowest number since 1973 (44).

qapairs: [{"answer": "James Liebman", "question": "Who was a professor of law at Columbia Law School?"}, {"answer": "47", "question": "How many percent of habeas corpus petitions were granted between 1976 and 1991?"}, {"answer": "definitional", "question": "What are the different numbers of habeas corpus petitions involving death row inmates largely?"}, {"answer": "Freedam", "question": "Who looks at the percentage of all death penalty cases reversed?"}]
context: James Liebman, a professor of law at Columbia Law School, stated in 1996 that his study found that when habeas corpus petitions in death penalty cases were traced from conviction to completion of the case that there was "a 40 percent success rate in all capital cases from 1978 to 1995." Similarly, a study by Ronald Tabak in a law review article puts the success rate in habeas corpus cases involving death row inmates even higher, finding that between "1976 and 1991, approximately 47 percent of the habeas petitions filed by death row inmates were granted." The different numbers are largely definitional, rather than substantive. Freedam's statistics looks at the percentage of all death penalty cases reversed, while the others look only at cases not reversed prior to habeas corpus review.

qapairs: [{"answer": "March 30, 1960", "question": "When did Utah shot James W. Rodgers?"}, {"answer": "June 22, 1965", "question": "When did Kansas hang George York?"}, {"answer": "August 10, 1966", "question": "When did Oklahoma electrocute James French?"}, {"answer": "June 2, 1967", "question": "When was Luis Monge gassed?"}]
context: The last use of the firing squad between 1608 and the moratorium on judicial executions between 1967 and 1977 was when Utah shot James W. Rodgers on March 30, 1960. The last use of the gallows between 1608 and the moratorium was when Kansas hanged George York on June 22, 1965. The last use of the electric chair between the first electrocution on August 6, 1890 and the moratorium was when Oklahoma electrocuted James French on August 10, 1966. The last use of the gas chamber between the first gassing on February 8, 1924 and the moratorium was when Colorado gassed Luis Monge on June 2, 1967.

qapairs: [{"answer": "364", "question": "How many juvenile offenders have been put to death by the states and the federal government since 1642?"}, {"answer": "Thomas Graunger", "question": "Who was the earliest known execution of a prisoner for crimes committed as a juvenile?"}, {"answer": "Twenty-two", "question": "How many of the executions occurred after 1976?"}, {"answer": "slow process of appeals", "question": "Why was it unusual for a condemned person to be under 18 at the time of execution?"}, {"answer": "George Stinney", "question": "Who was the youngest person to be executed in the 20th century?"}, {"answer": "Leonard Shockley", "question": "Who died in the Maryland gas chamber on April 10, 1959?"}, {"answer": "19", "question": "No one has been under what age at the time of execution since at least 1964?"}, {"answer": "22", "question": "How many people have been executed since 1976?"}, {"answer": "Twenty-one", "question": "How many people were 17 at the time of the crime?"}, {"answer": "Scott Hain", "question": "Who was the last person to be executed for a crime committed as a juvenile?"}]
context: Since 1642 (in the 13 colonies, the United States under the Articles of Confederation, and the current United States) an estimated 364 juvenile offenders have been put to death by the states and the federal government. The earliest known execution of a prisoner for crimes committed as a juvenile was Thomas Graunger in 1642. Twenty-two of the executions occurred after 1976, in seven states. Due to the slow process of appeals, it was highly unusual for a condemned person to be under 18 at the time of execution. The youngest person to be executed in the 20th century was George Stinney, who was electrocuted in South Carolina at the age of 14 on June 16, 1944. The last execution of a juvenile may have been Leonard Shockley, who died in the Maryland gas chamber on April 10, 1959, at the age of 17. No one has been under age 19 at time of execution since at least 1964. Since the reinstatement of the death penalty in 1976, 22 people have been executed for crimes committed under the age of 18. Twenty-one were 17 at the time of the crime. The last person to be executed for a crime committed as a juvenile was Scott Hain on April 3, 2003 in Oklahoma.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Robert Patton", "question": "Who was Oklahoma's Director of Corrections in May 2014?"}, {"answer": "43 minutes", "question": "How long did Clayton Lockett die of a heart attack?"}, {"answer": "nitrogen asphyxiation", "question": "What method of execution was approved by Oklahoma in 2015?"}]
context: In May 2014, Oklahoma Director of Corrections, Robert Patton, recommended an indefinite hold on executions in the state after the botched execution of African-American Clayton Lockett. The prisoner had to be tasered to restrain him prior to the execution, and the lethal injection missed a vein in his groin, resulting in Lockett regaining consciousness, trying to get up, and to speak, before dying of a heart attack 43 minutes later, after the attempted execution had been called off. In 2015, the state approved nitrogen asphyxiation as a method of execution.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Sixteen", "question": "What was the minimum permissible age in the 1988 Supreme Court decision of Thompson v. Oklahoma?"}, {"answer": "Roper v. Simmons", "question": "What case was considered by the Supreme Court in 2005?"}, {"answer": "State laws have not been updated to conform with this decision", "question": "What did the Supreme Court find the execution of juvenile offenders unconstitutional by a 5\u20134 margin?"}, {"answer": "unenforceable", "question": "What do unconstitutional laws do not need to be repealed?"}, {"answer": "List of juvenile offenders executed in the United States", "question": "What is the name of the list of juvenile offenders executed in the United States?"}]
context: Sixteen was held to be the minimum permissible age in the 1988 Supreme Court decision of Thompson v. Oklahoma. The Court, considering the case Roper v. Simmons in March 2005, found the execution of juvenile offenders unconstitutional by a 5–4 margin, effectively raising the minimum permissible age to 18. State laws have not been updated to conform with this decision. In the American legal system, unconstitutional laws do not need to be repealed; instead, they are held to be unenforceable. (See also List of juvenile offenders executed in the United States)

qapairs: [{"answer": "1986", "question": "When did previous post-Furman mass clemencies occur?"}, {"answer": "Governor Toney Anaya", "question": "Who commuted all death sentences because of his personal opposition to the death penalty?"}, {"answer": "eight", "question": "How many prisoners did Dick Celeste commute in 1991?"}, {"answer": "Dick Celeste", "question": "Who commuted the sentences of eight prisoners in 1991?"}, {"answer": "Bob Graham", "question": "Who was Florida's Governor during his two terms?"}]
context: Previous post-Furman mass clemencies took place in 1986 in New Mexico, when Governor Toney Anaya commuted all death sentences because of his personal opposition to the death penalty. In 1991, outgoing Ohio Governor Dick Celeste commuted the sentences of eight prisoners, among them all four women on the state's death row. And during his two terms (1979–1987) as Florida's Governor, Bob Graham, although a strong death penalty supporter who had overseen the first post-Furman involuntary execution as well as 15 others, agreed to commute the sentences of six people on the grounds of "possible innocence" or "disproportionality."

qapairs: [{"answer": "2010", "question": "In what year were bills to abolish the death penalty rejected?"}, {"answer": "Donald Moeller", "question": "Who was executed on October 30, 2012?"}, {"answer": "Paul Ezra Rhoades", "question": "Who was executed on November 18, 2011?"}, {"answer": "11", "question": "How many Nevada prisoners waived their rights to appeal?"}, {"answer": "two", "question": "How many prisoners have been executed against their will?"}, {"answer": "one", "question": "How many prisoners did Colorado and Wyoming execute in 1992?"}]
context: In 2010, bills to abolish the death penalty in Kansas and in South Dakota (which had a de facto moratorium at the time) were rejected. Idaho ended its de facto moratorium, during which only one volunteer had been executed, on November 18, 2011 by executing Paul Ezra Rhoades; South Dakota executed Donald Moeller on October 30, 2012, ending a de facto moratorium during which only two volunteers had been executed. Of the 12 prisoners whom Nevada has executed since 1976, 11 waived their rights to appeal. Kentucky and Montana have executed two prisoners against their will (KY: 1997 and 1999, MT: 1995 and 1998) and one volunteer, respectively (KY: 2008, MT: 2006). Colorado (in 1997) and Wyoming (in 1992) have executed only one prisoner, respectively.

qapairs: [{"answer": "1764", "question": "When was Of Crimes and Punishments published?"}, {"answer": "22", "question": "How many languages was Beccaria's masterpiece translated into?"}, {"answer": "1783", "question": "When was Saggi Politici published?"}]
context: Cesare Beccaria, a jurist and one of the great Enlightenment writers, became famous for his masterpiece Of Crimes and Punishments (1764), which was later translated into 22 languages. Another prominent intellectual was Francesco Mario Pagano, who wrote important studies such as Saggi Politici (Political Essays, 1783), one of the major works of the Enlightenment in Naples, and Considerazioni sul processo criminale (Considerations on the criminal trial, 1787), which established him as an international authority on criminal law.

qapairs: [{"answer": "French Revolution of 1789", "question": "What was the Enlightenment often linked to?"}, {"answer": "the \"consent of the governed\" philosophy", "question": "What is one view of the political changes that occurred during the Enlightenment?"}, {"answer": "violent revolution", "question": "What was the result of the revolutions of the late 1700s and early 1800s?"}, {"answer": "citizens by natural law had to consent to the acts and rulings of their government", "question": "What did a governance philosophy where the king was never wrong do?"}]
context: The Enlightenment has been frequently linked to the French Revolution of 1789. One view of the political changes that occurred during the Enlightenment is that the "consent of the governed" philosophy as delineated by Locke in Two Treatises of Government (1689) represented a paradigm shift from the old governance paradigm under feudalism known as the "divine right of kings". In this view, the revolutions of the late 1700s and early 1800s were caused by the fact that this governance paradigm shift often could not be resolved peacefully, and therefore violent revolution was the result. Clearly a governance philosophy where the king was never wrong was in direct conflict with one whereby citizens by natural law had to consent to the acts and rulings of their government.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Portland, Oregon", "question": "What is Seattle's neighbor?"}, {"answer": "same-sex marriage and reproductive rights", "question": "What issues are taken for granted in local politics?"}, {"answer": "2012", "question": "When did the majority of Seattleites vote to approve Referendum 74 and legalize gay marriage in Washington state?"}, {"answer": "cannabis", "question": "What recreational use did the majority of Seattleites vote to legalize in the state?"}, {"answer": "Pacific Northwest", "question": "What country has the lowest rate of church attendance in the United States?"}]
context: Seattle is widely considered one of the most liberal cities in the United States, even surpassing its neighbor, Portland, Oregon. Support for issues such as same-sex marriage and reproductive rights are largely taken for granted in local politics. In the 2012 U.S. general election, an overwhelming majority of Seattleites voted to approve Referendum 74 and legalize gay marriage in Washington state. In the same election, an overwhelming majority of Seattleites also voted to approve the legalization of the recreational use of cannabis in the state. Like much of the Pacific Northwest (which has the lowest rate of church attendance in the United States and consistently reports the highest percentage of atheism), church attendance, religious belief, and political influence of religious leaders are much lower than in other parts of America.

qapairs: [{"answer": "80%", "question": "How much of Seattle's population votes for the Democratic Party?"}, {"answer": "Barack Obama", "question": "Who did all precincts in Seattle vote for in 2012?"}, {"answer": "Democrats", "question": "Who wins nearly all elections for Washington State Legislature and United States Congress?"}, {"answer": "Bertha Knight Landes", "question": "Who is the first major American city to elect a female mayor?"}, {"answer": "Ed Murray", "question": "Who is the mayor of Seattle?"}, {"answer": "1991", "question": "When was Sherry Harris elected as a Seattle city councillor?"}, {"answer": "Sherry Harris", "question": "Who was elected as a Seattle city councillor in 1991?"}, {"answer": "female", "question": "What is the majority of Seattle's city council?"}]
context: Seattle's political culture is very liberal and progressive for the United States, with over 80% of the population voting for the Democratic Party. All precincts in Seattle voted for Democratic Party candidate Barack Obama in the 2012 presidential election. In partisan elections for the Washington State Legislature and United States Congress, nearly all elections are won by Democrats. Seattle is considered the first major American city to elect a female mayor, Bertha Knight Landes. It has also elected an openly gay mayor, Ed Murray, and a socialist councillor, Kshama Sawant. For the first time in United States history, an openly gay black woman was elected to public office when Sherry Harris was elected as a Seattle city councillor in 1991. The majority of the current city council is female, while white men comprise a minority.

qapairs: [{"answer": "allowing citizens to pass or reject laws", "question": "What is one of the ballot initiatives in Washington?"}, {"answer": "Jim McDermott", "question": "Who was elected in 1988?"}, {"answer": "Ed Murray", "question": "Who is currently serving as mayor of Seattle?"}]
context: Like most parts of the United States, government and laws are also run by a series of ballot initiatives (allowing citizens to pass or reject laws), referenda (allowing citizens to approve or reject legislation already passed), and propositions (allowing specific government agencies to propose new laws/tax increases directly to the people). Federally, Seattle is part of Washington's 7th congressional district, represented by Democrat Jim McDermott, elected in 1988 and one of Congress's liberal members. Ed Murray is currently serving as mayor.

qapairs: [{"answer": "one-drop rule", "question": "What was enacted in Virginia's 1924 Racial Integrity Law?"}, {"answer": "multiracial ancestry", "question": "What type of ancestry did people bury fading memories that many whites had?"}, {"answer": "multiracial", "question": "Many families were what type of ancestry?"}, {"answer": "South Carolina and Virginia", "question": "Where were similar laws proposed but not passed in the late nineteenth century?"}, {"answer": "Jim Crow", "question": "Who did white Democrats pass laws to impose to restore white supremacy?"}, {"answer": "1960s", "question": "In what decade did white Democrats pass laws to impose Jim Crow and racial segregation to restore white supremacy?"}]
context: Racial discrimination continued to be enacted in new laws in the 20th century, for instance the one-drop rule was enacted in Virginia's 1924 Racial Integrity Law and in other southern states, in part influenced by the popularity of eugenics and ideas of racial purity. People buried fading memories that many whites had multiracial ancestry. Many families were multiracial. Similar laws had been proposed but not passed in the late nineteenth century in South Carolina and Virginia, for instance. After regaining political power in Southern states by disenfranchising blacks, white Democrats passed laws to impose Jim Crow and racial segregation to restore white supremacy. They maintained these until forced to change in the 1960s and after by enforcement of federal legislation authorizing oversight of practices to protect the constitutional rights of African Americans and other minority citizens.

qapairs: [{"answer": "chief Ashkenazi rabbi", "question": "What authority do religious Ashkenazi Jews follow in halakhic matters?"}, {"answer": "an Israeli", "question": "What is a religiously Ashkenazi Jew?"}, {"answer": "Jewish religious parties", "question": "What does a portion of the Israeli electorate vote for?"}, {"answer": "120", "question": "How many seats does the Knesset have?"}]
context: Religious Ashkenazi Jews living in Israel are obliged to follow the authority of the chief Ashkenazi rabbi in halakhic matters. In this respect, a religiously Ashkenazi Jew is an Israeli who is more likely to support certain religious interests in Israel, including certain political parties. These political parties result from the fact that a portion of the Israeli electorate votes for Jewish religious parties; although the electoral map changes from one election to another, there are generally several small parties associated with the interests of religious Ashkenazi Jews. The role of religious parties, including small religious parties that play important roles as coalition members, results in turn from Israel's composition as a complex society in which competing social, economic, and religious interests stand for election to the Knesset, a unicameral legislature with 120 seats.

qapairs: [{"answer": "several", "question": "How many provinces was the empire divided into?"}, {"answer": "khalifah", "question": "Who appointed the governor of each province?"}, {"answer": "religious officials, army leaders, police, and civil administrators", "question": "Who was the governor in Damascus?"}, {"answer": "taxes coming from that province", "question": "Local expenses were paid for by what?"}, {"answer": "some governors neglected to send the extra tax revenue to Damascus", "question": "Why did some governors fail to send the extra tax revenue to Damascus?"}]
context: Geographically, the empire was divided into several provinces, the borders of which changed numerous times during the Umayyad reign. Each province had a governor appointed by the khalifah. The governor was in charge of the religious officials, army leaders, police, and civil administrators in his province. Local expenses were paid for by taxes coming from that province, with the remainder each year being sent to the central government in Damascus. As the central power of the Umayyad rulers waned in the later years of the dynasty, some governors neglected to send the extra tax revenue to Damascus and created great personal fortunes.

qapairs: [{"answer": "Umayyads", "question": "Who was criticized for having too many non-Muslim, former Roman administrators in their government?"}, {"answer": "St John of Damascus", "question": "Who was a high administrator in the Umayyad administration?"}, {"answer": "the peoples political representatives and the Roman tax collectors and the administrators", "question": "What did the Muslims leave as they took over cities?"}, {"answer": "the peoples political representatives", "question": "Who calculated and negotiated the taxes to the central government?"}, {"answer": "The Central government", "question": "Who got paid for the services it provided?"}, {"answer": "maintain their churches and run their own organizations", "question": "What did many Christian cities use some of the taxes on?"}, {"answer": "not reducing the taxes of the people who converted to Islam", "question": "Why were the Umayyads criticized?"}, {"answer": "new converts", "question": "Who continues to pay the same taxes that were previously negotiated?"}]
